== Renminbi hubs outside China ==
''[need elaboration on the benefits of RMB Clearing Banks outside of mainland and [[China International Payments System]] (CIPS)]''
=== Australia ===
China is Australia's largest trading partner (AUD 120bn in 2013) and in March 2012, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) signed the 3-year RMB Bilateral Swap Agreement with the PBoC worth RMB200bn.
18 February 2014, the Australian Securities Exchange Limited ("ASX") and BoC signed an agreement for clearing and settlement in RMB (in Australia). In April, the RBA announced that it would invest up to 5% of its foreign reserves in RMB Sovereign bond.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.cifr.edu.au/assets/document/Chi-wah%20Chung.pdf|title = Renminbi Internationalisation|date = March 2014|accessdate = January 21, 2015|website = Centre for International Finance and Regulation (CIFR)|publisher = |last = Chung|first = Chi-wah}}</ref> On November 17, RBA and PBoC signed an MOU to established official RMB Clearing arrangements in Australia and PBoC granted RMB 50bn RQFII quota to Australia, which will allow approved Australian domiciled FI to invest in China's domestic bond and equity markets using RMB.<ref name=":7" />
=== Canada ===
On 8 November 2014, Canada became the first country in the Americas to sign a reciprocal currency deal with China, enabling direct business between the Canadian dollar and the Chinese yuan.<ref name="The Canadian Press Posted: Nov 08, 2014">{{cite news|agency=The Canadian Press |work =CBC News |title=Canada, China sign currency deal aimed at boosting trade|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/canada-china-sign-currency-deal-aimed-at-boosting-trade-1.2828707|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref>
=== Germany (BoC) ===
On 19 June 2014, Based on the MoU signed by the People’s Bank of China and the Bundesbank, the PBoC has authorized the Frankfurt Branch of Bank of China to serve as the RMB clearing bank in Frankfurt.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.pbc.gov.cn/publish/english/955/2014/20140630152824765992284/20140630152824765992284_.html|title = The PBC Announcement [2014] No.12|date = 27 June 2014|accessdate = 23 July 2014|website = |publisher = PBC}}</ref> China is EU's No. 1 supplier of goods and its third largest export market. Eu-China annual trade could grow 1.5 times in a decade's time (to EUR 660bn). Germany is China's largest trading partner in the EU (EUR 138.6bn in 2013), which accounted for 45% of EU's exports to China and 28% of EU's imports from China. The RMB was used for 29% in the eurozone (and 38% of non-eurozone Europe's) from 19% a year earlier. The volume of RMB deposit has climbed to 100bn at end-2013.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://www.dbresearch.de/MAIL/DBR_INTERNET_DE-PROD/PROD0000000000339508.pdf|title = China-EU relations: Gearing up for growth|last = Hanskul|first = Syetam|date = 31 July 2014|journal = Deutsche Bank Research|accessdate = 14 October 2014|doi = |pmid = }}</ref>
=== Hong Kong and Macau (BoC) ===
Since 2010 CNH deposit has grown 12 times from RMB 90 bn to 1,125 bn by 1H2014 while Trade Settlement handled by Hong Kong Banks and CNH Bond outstanding increases 107 times (RMB 27 bn to 2,926 bn) and 12 times (RMB 30 bn to 384 bn) respectively.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.hkma.gov.hk/media/eng/doc/key-information/speeches/20140915e1a1.pdf|title = What does it take to develop a Global Offshore RMB Hub?|date = 15 September 2014|accessdate = 17 September 2014|website = 2014 Treasury Markets Summit, Hong Kong Monetary Authority|publisher = Hong Kong Monetary Authority|last = Chan|first = Norman T.L.}}</ref> As of 2014, Hong Kong is still the largest offshore RMB (CNH) hubs outside of mainland China. On 10 April, CSRC and Hong Kong's SFC jointly announced Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect (SHKSC) pilot programme – which allows Hong Kong investors to buy Shanghai-listed A-shares and vice versa – is scheduled to start operation on 13 October 2014 with the quota for inward investments in A-shares by Hong Kong residents of CNY 300bn <ref name=":6" /> (the actual opening was on 17 November where the daily limited was reached, mainly from the Northbound trade, after market opened less than 5 hours).
=== London (CCB) ===
In 2013, London accounted for over 60% percent of all renminbi-denominated trade activity outside Chinese territory,<ref name="govukosborne">{{cite web|title=Groundbreaking deal set to make London global currency centre for investment in China|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/groundbreaking-deal-set-to-make-london-global-currency-centre-for-investment-in-china|publisher=[[Gov.uk]]|accessdate=22 October 2013}}</ref> with daily volume rising to £3.1 billion.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tania Branigan|title=Boost for London as China agrees to loosen yuan investment rules|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2013/oct/15/london-china-investment-rules-yuan|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|accessdate=22 October 2013}}</ref>
On 18 June 2014, PBoC appointed [[China Construction Bank]] (London) to serve as the RMB Clearing Bank in London.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.pbc.gov.cn/publish/english/955/2014/20140630152117110308522/20140630152117110308522_.html|title = The PBC Announcement [2014] No.11|date = 27 June 2014|accessdate = 23 July 2014|website = |publisher = PBC}}</ref> The UK leads Europe with 123.6% growth in RMB payment between July 2013 to July 2014.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.swift.com/assets/swift_com/documents/products_services/RMB_tracker_Aug2014_SdC.pdf|title = European hubs are fuelling RMB Internationalisation|date = 25 August 2014|work = SWIFT|accessdate = 29 September 2014}}</ref>
=== Luxembourg ===
In May 2011, the first [[Dim sum bond]] issued by a European company outside Greater China was listed on the [[Luxembourg Stock Exchange]].<ref>http://shanghai.mae.lu/en/Actualites/RMB-Business-in-Luxembourg</ref>
In the first quarter of 2014, Luxembourg confirmed its position as the number one in renminbi business in Europe and the third worldwide. RMB deposits increased by 24% to ¥79.4bn compared to 2013 year's end.<ref>http://www.pwc.lu/en/china/docs/pwc-where-do-you-renminbi.pdf</ref>
In May 2014, the first Dim Sum bond issued by a Chinese entity in the [[Eurozone]] was listed at the Luxembourg Stock Exchange, the so-called [[Schengen bond]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20140514000004&cid=1203 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018090539/http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20140514000004&cid=1203 |archivedate=18 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Luxembourg is the largest RMB securities settlement centre and leading place for RMB denominated bonds in Europe with RMB 79bn in deposits and over RMB 261 bn in investment funds registered.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.rmb-business.com/en/rmb-in-luxembourg/overview|title = Overview of Cross-Border Renminbi Activities|date = 2014|accessdate = 17 September 2014|website = Luxembourg for Finance|publisher = }}</ref>
=== Malaysia ===
In October 2011, Khazanah Nasional Bhd issued the first ever offshore RMB denominated sukuk, raising RMB500m .
In July 2014, SWIFT ranked Malaysia as top ten offshore RMB centres. Its RMB trade settlement volume as tripled since 2010 to RMB3bn (in 2013) while RMB deposit to (10.7bn) and FX volume ($580m per day) increased more than ten and fifteenfold since 2010 respectively. As of mid-2014, Malaysian firm's RMB Bond issuance reached RMB4.4bn.<ref name=":8" />
=== Moscow ===
On 15 December 2010, the [[Moscow Interbank Currency Exchange]] (MICEX) became the first regulated market to trade the renminbi outside China, with a relatively modest first session turnover of ¥4.9 million, or 22.8 million [[Russian ruble|rubles]], after one hour of trading.<ref>{{cite web|last=Oleg Nikishenkov|title=Betting on the yuan|url=http://themoscownews.com/business/20101220/188295842.html|publisher=''[[The Moscow News]]''|date=20 December 2010}}</ref>
In 2011, MICEX was incorporated into the [[Moscow Exchange]] where the renminbi continued to trade against the ruble. In 2012, the volume of renminbi traded increased by 70% compared to the previous year.<ref>{{cite web|title=New trading record on the Moscow Exchange's FX market|url=http://rts.micex.ru/n3293/?nt=201|publisher=[[Moscow Exchange]]|accessdate=22 October 2013}}</ref>
From April to June 2013, the average daily value of renminbi traded on the Moscow Exchange grew nearly fourfold, surpassing ¥30 million for the first time. On 3 July 2013, it reached an all-time high of ¥55.2 million.<ref>{{cite web|title=New record of the Moscow Exchange's FX market|url=http://rts.micex.ru/n3510|publisher=[[Moscow Exchange]]|accessdate=22 October 2013}}</ref>
=== Paris ===
In 2013, renminbi-denominated deposits in Paris amounted to ¥10 billion, making it the second largest pool of Chinese currency in Europe after London.<ref>{{cite news|title=France plans currency swap line with China: paper|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/04/13/us-china-france-currency-idUSBRE93C01S20130413|publisher=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=22 October 2013|quote=Yuan deposits in Paris amount to 10 billion yuan ($1.6 billion), making it the second largest pool for the Chinese currency in Europe after London. Almost 10 percent of Sino-French trade is settled in yuan, also called the renminbi or RMB, according to French data cited by the official newspaper.|date=13 April 2013}}</ref>
=== Singapore (ICBC) ===
[[File:Downtown Core Singapore March 2011 (Landscape).jpg|thumb|In 2013, the [[city-state]] of [[Singapore]] became the world's 3rd largest [[Foreign exchange market|foreign exchange]] (FX) hub, lagging behind only the United Kingdom and the United States<ref>{{cite news|title=Singapore Overtakes Japan as Asia’s Top Foreign-Exchange Hub|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-09-05/singapore-overtakes-japan-as-asia-s-biggest-foreign-exchange-hub.html|publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]|accessdate=22 October 2013}}</ref> In October that year, plans for the [[Singapore Dollar]] to trade directly against the renminbi were finalized.<ref name="massg">{{cite web|title=New Initiatives to Strengthen China-Singapore Financial Cooperation|url=http://www.mas.gov.sg/news-and-publications/press-releases/2013/new-initiatives-to-strengthen-china-singapore-financial-cooperation.aspx|publisher=[[Monetary Authority of Singapore]]|accessdate=22 October 2013}}</ref>]]
According to the [[Monetary Authority of Singapore]] (MAS), the usage of the renminbi in Singapore has increased by 40% since 2012, with total renminbi-denominated deposits valued at more than ¥140 billion.<ref>{{cite web|title=Use of China currency up 40% in Singapore |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/business/singapore/use-of-china-currency-up/821142.html |publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]] |accessdate=22 October 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KYf6TA9E?url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/business/singapore/use-of-china-currency-up/821142.html |archivedate=22 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 7 February 2013, PBoC designated [[Industrial and Commercial Bank of China|ICBC]] (Singapore) as the yuan Clearing Bank in Singapore.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://thechinatimes.com/online/2013/02/6605.html|title = ICBC appointed as yuan clearing bank in Singapore|date = 8 February 2013|accessdate = 23 July 2014|website = |publisher = The China Times}}</ref>
On 7 March 2013, PBoC renew the 3-year BSA with MAS and double the facility to ¥150bn (30 billion [[Singapore Dollar|Singapore dollars]])<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.pbc.gov.cn/publish/english/955/2013/20130313140427964275661/20130313140427964275661_.html|title = People’s Bank of China and Monetary Authority of Singapore Signed a New Bilateral Currency Swap Agreement to Double the Size of Swap Facility|date = 13 March 2013|accessdate = 23 July 2014|website = |publisher = PBC}}</ref>
In June 2014, PBoC and MAS jointly announced the [[Suzhou Industrial Park]] (SIP) initiative, which clearly suggested China's recognition of Singapore as an offshore Yuan center following Hong Kong (with Qianhai) and Taiwan (with Kunshan).<ref>{{Cite news|url = |title = OCBC China Insights, Singapore-China SIP initiative marks another milestone for RMB internationalization|date = 13 June 2014|work = OCBC Treasury Research|accessdate = }}</ref>
On 28 October 2014 direct currency trading started between the Singapore dollar and the renminbi (CNY/SGD).<ref>{{cite web|title=Singapore and China Further Strengthen Financial Cooperation Through New Initiatives|url=http://www.mas.gov.sg/News-and-Publications/Media-Releases/2014/Singapore-and-China-further-strengthen-financial-cooperation-through-new-initiatives.aspx|publisher=[[Monetary Authority of Singapore]]|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref> The Singapore dollar was added to the China Foreign Exchange Trade System's (CFETS) platform, which as of 28 October 2014 offers financial operations and transactions between the yuan and ten foreign currencies.<ref>{{cite web|title=China, Singapore Start Direct Currency Trading|url=http://wbponline.com/Articles/View/37606/china-singapore-start-direct-currency-trading|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref>
=== South Korea (BoCOM) ===
On 4 July 2014, PBoC appointed Bank of Communication (Seoul) as the RMB Clearing Bank in South Korea.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.chinamoneynetwork.com/2014/07/05/china-plants-rmb-clearing-banks-around-the-world|title = China Plants RMB Clearing Banks Around The World|date = 5 July 2014|accessdate = 23 July 2014|website = |publisher = China Money Network|last = Liu|first = Li-Gang}}</ref>
=== Switzerland ===
On 21 July 2014, the People’s Bank of China and the Swiss National Bank had signed a bilateral currency swap agreement.<ref name="FT20140721">{{cite web|author1=James Shotter |author2=Gabriel Wildau |title=China and Switzerland sign bilateral currency swap line|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d79001d8-10b8-11e4-812b-00144feabdc0.html|publisher=''[[Financial Times|Financial Times Limited]]''|accessdate=21 July 2014}}</ref>
=== Taiwan (BoC) ===
On 11 December 2012, PBoC authorized Bank of China (Taipei) to serve as RMB Clearing Bank in Taiwan.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.pbc.gov.cn/publish/english/955/2013/20130314105541578282714/20130314105541578282714_.html|title = Highlights of China’s Monetary Policy in 2012|date = 25 February 2013|accessdate = 23 July 2014|website = |publisher = PBC}}</ref> The CNH deposit in Taiwan at RMB 301bn is second only to Hong Kong (945 bn) as of November 2014.
=== Tokyo ===
In 2012, direct transactions between the [[Japanese yen]] and the renminbi began, with [[Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation]] acting as the first major Japanese bank to accept deposits in renminbi.<ref>{{cite web|last=TOKUHIKO SAITO|title=SMBC first major bank to accept deposits in yuan|url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/economy/business/AJ201207160001|publisher=''[[Asahi Shimbun]]''|accessdate=22 October 2013}}</ref>
== List of foreign banks, that trade renminbi ==
*[[HSBC]] *[[Standard Chartered Bank]] *[[Credit Agricole CIB]] *[[Deutsche Bank]] *[[Bank of America]] *[[Citigroup]] *[[Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group]] *[[Japan Post Bank]] *[[Bank of East Asia]] *[[Bank of Singapore]] *[[DBS Bank]] *[[Busan Bank]] *[[Daegu Bank]] *[[KASIKORNBANK]] *[[Bangkok Bank]] *[[Siam Commercial Bank]] *[[Bank of the Philippine Islands]] *[[Malayan Banking Berhad]] *[[Commonwealth Bank of Australia]]
== Criticism ==
The German news magazine ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' criticized China for "forcing other countries to maintain reserves of Chinese money" in a bid to attain "economic [[hegemony]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=Exchange Rates and Reserve Currencies: China Plans Path to Economic Hegemony|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/business/exchange-rates-and-reserve-currencies-china-plans-path-to-economic-hegemony-a-741303.html|publisher=''[[Der Spiegel]]''|accessdate=22 October 2013}}</ref>
[[Gordon G. Chang]], author of ''[[The Coming Collapse of China]]'', argued that China’s "excessively selfish" currency policy does not sit well with other nations, and such efforts to loosen control of the renminbi is part of China's ploy to deflect international pressure.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gordon G. Chang|title=China's Currency Ploy|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2010/06/21/chinas-move-toward-floating-yuan-is-a-ploy.html|publisher=''[[The Daily Beast]]''|accessdate=20 June 2010}}</ref>
==Use in Zimbabwe==
The RMB is now one of the currencies legal tender in Zimbabwe's multiple currency system.

{{Infobox Organization |name = '''Investment Industry Regulatory Organization of Canada''' |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = IIROC/OCRCVM |motto = |formation = 2008 |extinction = |type = Organizations based in Canada |status = active |purpose = Monitors members for securities law compliance; enforces securities regulations through quasi-judicial proceedings |headquarters = [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], [[Canada]] |location = |region_served = [[Canada]] |membership = |language = [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]] |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = http://www.iiroc.ca/ www.iiroc.ca/ |remarks = }}
The '''Investment Industry Regulatory Organization of Canada''' ('''IIROC'''; ''Organisme Canadien de réglementation du commerce des valeurs mobilières'' or ''OCRCVM'' in French) is a non-profit, national [[self-regulatory organization]] (SRO). Established through the merger of the [[Investment Dealers Association of Canada]] (IDA) and [[Market Regulation Services Inc.]] (RS) on June 1, 2008,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.osc.gov.on.ca/MarketRegulation/SRO/sro_index.jsp|title=Self-regulatory organizations (SROs) |publisher=[[Ontario Securities Commission]] |accessdate=2008-08-20 }}</ref> IIROC oversees all investment dealers and trading activity on debt and equity markets in [[Canada]].
The organization sets regulatory and investment industry standards and has quasi-judicial powers in that it holds enforcement hearings and has the power to suspend, fine and expel members and registered representatives, such as advisers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.investmentexecutive.com/client/en/News/DetailNews.asp?Id=45560&cat=8&IdSection=8&PageMem=&nbNews= |title=IIROC imposes $2 million fine on TD Waterhouse |first=Kate |last=Betts-Willmott |work=[[Investment Executive]] |date=2008-07-31 |accessdate=2008-08-14 }}</ref> However, it has often been criticized by investor advocates as ineffective.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.investorvoice.ca/IDA/Comset/Comset_12Feb07.htm |title=Advocate flouts regulator |first=Gary |last=Norris |work=[[The Canadian Press]] |date=2007-02-12 |accessdate=2008-08-14 }}</ref>
==History==
IIROC was formed on June 1, 2008 through the merger of the Investment Dealers Association of Canada (IDA) and Market Regulation Services Inc. (RS).
The Bond Dealers Section of the [[Toronto Board of Trade]] was formed in 1916 as a trade organization to coordinate financing of Canada's war effort. It was renamed the Investment Dealers Association of Canada in 1934. Throughout most of its history, the IDA serve both as a regulator and as an advocacy organization for the securities dealers. In 2006, IDA narrowed its focus to regulation and transferred its industry association role to a new separate and independent industry association, the Investment Industry Association of Canada.
Market Regulation Services Inc. was formed in 2008 in response to the implementation of National Instruments 21-101 ''Marketplace Operation'' and 23-101 ''Trading Rules'', which require an independent regulation services provider to regulate trading in all Canadian marketplaces, including the [[Toronto Stock Exchange|TSX]].
==Management== Andrew J. Kriegler was appointed President and Chief Executive Officer of IIROC on November 1, 2014.<ref>http://business.financialpost.com/2014/09/03/andrew-kriegler-iiroc/</ref> Before joining IIROC, Kriegler was Deputy Superintendent at Canada's banking regulator, the [[Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions (Canada)|Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions]], or OSFI, where he was responsible for supervising hundreds of federally regulated financial institutions.
Kriegler succeeds Susan Wolburgh Jenah, who headed IIROC's predecessor, the Investment Dealers Association of Canada (IDA) before becoming IIROC's first President and CEO in 2008. At the IDA, she had taken over the post from [[Joe Oliver (politician)|Joe Oliver]], who was alter elected as a Member of Parliament and went on to serve as federal [[Minister of Finance (Canada)|Minister of Finance]].
==Operations== IIROC operates under Recognition Orders from the [[Canadian Securities Administrators]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.investmentexecutive.com/client/en/News/DetailNews.asp?IdPub=163&Id=44367&cat=27&IdSection=27&PageMem=&nbNews= |title=Long wait almost over for merged regulator |last=Langton |first=James |work=[[Investment Executive]] |date=May 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-14 }}</ref> (CSA), which is the umbrella for Canada's provincial and territorial securities regulators. IIROC is subject to CSA oversight and regular operational reviews.
===Regulatory failures=== ====Loss of unencrypted private investor data==== The CSA (Canadian Securities Administrators) investigated IIROC for the loss of personal financial data of thousands of brokerage clients after IIROC announced that it lost a mobile device containing the information. The device had not been encrypted, which is in violation of IIROC policy. The case reviewed IIROC's current policies, controls and procedures around information security.<ref name="IE CSA Review">{{cite news | title = CSA reviewing IIROC data loss | publisher = [[Investment Executive]] | url = http://www.investmentexecutive.com/-/csa-reviewing-iiroc-data-loss | accessdate = 26 April 2013}}</ref>
More than 50,000 Canadian brokerage clients, from 32 investment firms, had personal financial information on the device. At least one source has called the incident a cover up.<ref name="FP Explanation">{{cite news | title = IIROC broke own rules by losing private data — can we believe its explanation | publisher = [[The Financial Post]] | url = http://business.financialpost.com/2013/04/29/iiroc-broke-its-own-rules-by-losing-data-device-can-we-believe-its-explanation/ | date = 29 April 2013}}</ref>
====Charges against David Berry==== IIROC charged David Berry with securities law violations that were used by Scotiabank as grounds for his dismissal. David Berry claims his dismissal and the reputation damage stemming from the IIROC charges have cost him $105M dollars. <ref name="Scotiabank Fallout">{{cite news | title = Scotiabank explored fallout of cutting star trader's $15M pay months before he was fired, documents suggest | publisher = [[Financial Post]] | url = http://business.financialpost.com/2012/10/19/scotiabank-explored-fallout-of-cutting-star-traders-15m-pay-months-before-he-was-fired-documents-suggest/ |date = 19 Oct 2012|deadurl=no}}</ref>
In a ruling on January 15, 2013, more than seven years after the initial accusation, a hearing panel of the IIROC dismissed all charges against Berry. <ref name="FP Broke Own">{{cite news | title = Former top Scotiabank trader cleared of allegations that led to his $100M wrongful dismissal lawsuit | publisher = [[The Financial Post]] | url = http://business.financialpost.com/2013/01/15/iiroc-charges-against-david-berry-dismissed/ |date = 15 January 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
====Charges against Blackmont Capital Inc. and Dean Shannon Duke==== In September 2010, IIROC contended that a Vancouver brokerage firm, Blackmont Capital Inc., and an employee, Dean Shannon Duke, acted against two IIROC rules in agreeing to share trading commissions with a third party. In December 2010, IIROC imposed penalties on both Blackmont Capital and Duke for splitting commissions with people associated with a client without the client's written consent. IIROC also imposed penalties for not disclosing the commission-sharing arrangement with its clients. Blackmont Capital and Duke were assessed a total of $857,500 in fines by IIROC.<ref name= blackmont/>
In 2011, the British Columbia Securities Commission (BCSC) overturned IIROC's decision and penalties against Blackmont Capital and Duke. A BCSC appeal panel contended that Blackmont and Duke's act of not disclosing their commission-sharing arrangement was not against public interest. The BCSC reversed IIROC's verdict and the imposing of its fines.<ref name="blackmont">{{cite news | title = Investment Industry Regulatory Organization deserves credit for decision in Blackmont Capital case | publisher = canada.com | url = http://www.canada.com/story_print.html?id=b666e47b-f235-4d9b-a75c-18580f245a2a |date = 5 Nov 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref>
====Charges against Evergreen Securities CCO==== An Oct. 2012 IIROC Hearing Panel dismissed all allegations made by IIROC against Evergreen Capital Partners Inc. executives Loretta Carbonelli and Gerald T.Conway. <ref name="IIROC News Release">{{cite news | title = IN THE MATTER OF Loretta Carbonelli and Gerald Trevor Conway - Allegations Dismissed | publisher = [[IIROC]] | url = http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/1055453/in-the-matter-of-loretta-carbonelli-and-gerald-trevor-conway-allegations-dismissed |date = 18 October 2012|deadurl=no}}</ref>
====Charges against Vic Alboini and Northern Securities Inc.==== In 2012, IIROC contended that activist investor, Vic Alboini, and two other executives at Northern Securities Inc. had improperly obtained credit for Jaguar Financial Corporation and had risked Northern Securities as a result. IIROC penalized Alboini with a suspension of two years, a permanent ban from being an "ultimate designated person" and fines totaling $750,000.
Northern Securities appealed IIROC's decision to the [[Ontario Securities Commission]] (OSC). The OSC overturned one count against Alboini and Northern Securities, namely that Alboini and Northern Securities had not corrected deficiencies found in IIROC compliance reviews. The OSC also overturned IIROC's penalties against Alboini and Northern Securities, saying that IIROC should not have announced serious penalties at the same time as their decision.<ref name="northern">{{cite news | title = IIROC won’t hold new hearing into compliance issues, Alboini says | publisher = [[The Globe and Mail]] | url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/iiroc-wont-hold-new-hearing-into-compliance-issues-says-alboini/article16920727/ |date = 5 Nov 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref>
====Charges against Carolann Steinhoff==== IIROC imposed charges against broker, Carolann Steinhoff. Focusing on Steinhoff's activities between 2004 and 2007, IIROC contended that Steinhoff had instructed her assistants to falsify client documents and that she had obstructed IIROC investigations. Part of IIROC's contentions related to Steinhoff's instruction to her assistant to cut and paste a client's signature from an existing form to an unsigned guarantee.
In 2011, the BCSC overturned IIROC's decision against Steinhoff. In overturning IRROC's decision, the BCSC stated that IIROC's ruling against Steinhoff was not supported by the objective evidence, but was made on the basis of character evidence. The BCSC panel also concluded that Steinhoff was entitled to defend herself and therefore overturned the charges against her for obstructing IIROC's investigation.<ref name="steinhoff">{{cite news | title = Victoria-based broker Carolann Steinhoff’s punishment too harsh, BCSC rules| publisher = [[The Vancouver Sun]] | url = http://www.vancouversun.com/business/Victoria+based+broker+Carolann+Steinhoff+punishment+harsh+BCSC+rules/8765577/story.html |date = 8 Aug 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
====Jurisdiction over former members dispute==== The organization has been involved in litigation over its power to discipline former members for their conduct while they were members. An [[Ontario Divisional Court]] decision in the matter of Stephen Taub ruled the [[Ontario Securities Act]] does not allow this.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://secure.globeadvisor.com/servlet/ArticleNews/story/gam/20080723/LAWCOLUMN23 |first=Jacquie |last=McNish |title=Lawyer finds gaping hole in securities law. |work=[[The Globe and Mail]] |date=2008-07-22 |accessdate=2008-08-14 }}</ref> The [[British Columbia Court of Appeal]] reached a different conclusion in the matter of [[Charles Dass]] and upheld a decision of the [[British Columbia Securities Commission]] that IIROC does have jurisdiction over former members.<ref>Investment Dealers Association of Canada v. Dass, 2008 BCCA 413</ref> Later the [[Ontario Court of Appeal]] reversed the [[Divisional Court]] decision and reached the same conclusion as the British Columbia Court.<ref>[[Taub v. Investment Dealers Association of Canada]], 2009 ONCA 628</ref> In [[Saskatchewan]] and [[Alberta]], provincial securities regulations state explicitly that self-regulatory organizations have the power to pursue enforcement activities with regards to former members.
==See also== *[[Canadian securities regulation]] *[[Universal Market Integrity Rules]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Commons}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.iiroc.ca/}}

{{Infobox Officeholder | name = István Herman | image = | imagesize = | order = [[National Assembly of Hungary|Member of the National Assembly]] | term_start = 14 May 2010 | term_end = 5 May 2014 | president = | predecessor = | successor = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1947|10|16|df=yes}} | birth_place = Aldebrő, [[Second Hungarian Republic|Hungary]] | profession = businessman, politician | party = [[Fidesz]] (since 2006) | otherparty = [[Hungarian Democratic Forum]]
[[Entrepreneurs' Party]] | spouse = | children = 2 |}} {{eastern name order|Herman István Ervin}} '''István Ervin Herman''' (born October 16, 1947){{cite web|url=http://www.parlament.hu/kepv/eletrajz/hu/h059.pdf |title=''Biography'' |publisher=[[National Assembly of Hungary|Országgyűlés]]}} is a Hungarian entrepreneur and politician, [[National Assembly of Hungary|member of the National Assembly]] (MP) for [[Füzesabony]] ([[Heves County]] Constituency VI) from 2010 to 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.parlament.hu/internet/plsql/ogy_kpv.kepv_adat?p_azon=h059&p_ckl=39 |title=''Register'' |publisher=[[National Assembly of Hungary|Országgyűlés]]}} ==Biography== He finished his secondary studies at the [[István Dobó|Dobó István]] Grammar School in [[Eger]] from 1963 to 1967. He learned [[zincography]] in the Kossuth Press in [[Budapest]]. He graduated pedagogy from the Eszterházy Károly College of Eger in 2002. ===Entrepreneurial career=== He co-founded the Grafotip Advertising and Trading Ltd. in 1989. He was appointed President of the Heves County Chamber of Crafts in 1995. He was the "Entrepreneur of the Year" in 1999. ===Political career=== Herman served as a representative in the Eger Assembly from 1990 to 1994. He was a member of the Committee on Budgets between 1994 and 1998. He became a member of the Heves County General Assembly in 1998. He functioned as deputy chairman of the [[Hungarian Democratic Forum]] (MDF) in Heves County between 2002 and 2005. He joined the [[Entrepreneurs' Party]] on October 30, 2005. He was elected chairman of the party on October 18, 2006, however the previous leader Antal Császár refused to recognize the victory, referring to formal reasons. Császár directed the case to legal proceedings who, finally, won the lawsuit in August 2008. Proceedings were initiated on suspicion of money laundering against Herman and his deputy chairman Tamás Janzsó in November 2007, because they opened a private account for managing the finances of the party, while the slush fund was blocked by the Court.[http://index.hu/politika/belfold/vp8763/ Pénzmosással gyanúsítanak két pártvezetőt], [[Index.hu]], 9 November 2007. Herman joined [[Fidesz]] in 2006 and became chairman of the 6th constituency of Heves County. He was elected to the National Assembly from that constituency in 2010. He was a member of the Committee on Audit Office and Budget since May 14, 2010 and of the Economic and Information Technology Committee since February 14, 2011. ==Personal life== He is married and has two sons.[http://nol.hu/belfold/20100427-fidesz_-_kdnp-639601 [[Népszabadság]] - Fidesz-KDNP] ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Herman, Istvan}} [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Hungarian businesspeople]] [[Category:Hungarian Democratic Forum politicians]] [[Category:Fidesz politicians]] [[Category:Members of the National Assembly of Hungary (2010–14)]]

[[File:Sede_AGCM.jpg|right|thumb|The seat of the AGCM, Rome]] The '''Italian Competition Authority''' ({{lang-it|Autorità Garante della Concorrenza e del Mercato}}, '''AGCM''') is an [[Italy|Italian]] [[Quango|quasi-autonomous non-governmental organization]] established on the basis of Law no 287 of 10 October 1990,<ref>[http://www.agcm.it/AGCM_ENG/NORMATIV/E_NORMNA.NSF/b50758bf27025fecc125653d00467db4?OpenView Law no. 287 of October 10th, 1990 (The Competition and Fair Trading Act)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20001210035400/http://www.agcm.it/AGCM_ENG/NORMATIV/E_NORMNA.NSF/b50758bf27025fecc125653d00467db4?OpenView |date=December 10, 2000 }}</ref> 100 years after the ''[[Sherman Antitrust Act]]''. As of 2004, the Italian Competition Authority has also been in charge of enforcing laws against conflicts of interest for Holders of Public Office.
As the Italian [[competition regulator]], the Authority has the task of enforcing both Italian and European consumer protection laws.
It is financed by annual allocations through a special chapter of the Ministry of Economic Development's budget. The Financial Law of 2006 introduced partial self-financing:<ref>Article 10(7-bis) of Law 287/90 as amended by article 1(69) of Law no. 266 of 2005.</ref> ''AGCM'' has full control over the management of these funds for its own operations.
An annual report is presented to the [[President of the Council of Ministers of Italy]].
==Duties== The main duties of the authority are: * Vigilance against abuses from [[Dominance (economics)|market dominance]]. * Vigilance against [[cartel]]s that may prejudice or restrict fair [[Competition (economics)|competition]] ([[Anti-competitive practices]]). * Vigilance on [[takeover]]s to check [[concentration ratio]] and verify [[market impact]]. * [[Consumer protection]], against unfair trade practices and [[false advertising]]. * Supervise and penalize the cases of [[conflict of interest]] regarding members of [[Council of Ministers of Italy|Government of Italy]].
==Powers== The Authority in such cases may conduct investigations or hearings, even with the [[Guardia di Finanza]] at his disposal, which may result in a warning or an administrative penalty.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{official website}} *[http://www.radioradicale.it/organizzatore/autorita-garante-della-concorrenza-e-del-mercato ''AGCM'' commission hearings] are available on [[Radio Radicale]] website (in Italian).

{{Infobox person |name = José Ferré |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = José Antonio Ferré Aguayo |birth_date = {{birth date|1902|9|12}} |birth_place = [[Ponce, Puerto Rico]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1990|9|15|1902|9|12}} |death_place = [[Puerto Rico]] |death_cause = |resting_place = |nationality = [[Puerto Rican people|Puerto Rican]] |other_names = |education = |employer = |occupation = Businessman |title = |parents = Antonio Ferré and Mary Aguayo }}
'''José Antonio Ferré Aguayo''' (September 12, 1902 – September 15, 1990) was a [[Puerto Rican people|Puerto Rican]] businessman, industrialist and government official. He was a brother of [[Luis A. Ferré|Luis Ferré]], who served as [[Governor of Puerto Rico]], and [[Isolina Ferré]], the "[[Mother Teresa]] of Puerto Rico". Ferré was also the father of [[Maurice Ferré]], a former six-term mayor of [[Miami, Florida]].<ref>{{cite book | title=Hispanics in American Politics: The Search for Political Power | first=Maurilio E. | last=Vigil | year=1987 | page=102 | chapter=Hispanics in Local Office- State and Local Levels}}</ref>
==Early life and education==
Ferré was born in Ponce and the son of Cuban born Antonio Ferré Bacallao.<ref name="Sarasota"/> After attending [[Morristown-Beard School#History|Morristown-School]] (now Morristown-Beard School) in [[Morristown, New Jersey]], he earned his bachelor's degree in business administration at [[Boston University]] in [[Boston, Massachusetts]] in 1924.<ref name="congressional record">{{USCongRec|1990|E3220}}</ref> Ferré later served on the Board of Trustees of the school alongside [[Edward Kennedy]].<ref>{{cite news | newspaper=The New York Times | title=Boston U Names a Kennedy | date=21 October 1961}} "Edward M. Kennedy, youngest brother of President Kennedy, was one of three persons elected today to the Board of Trustees of Boston University. Other elected were Stephen P. Mugar of Belmont, President of the Star Market Company, and Jose A. Ferre, industrialist."</ref> He earned his master's degree in business administration from the [[University of Miami]].<ref name="congressional record"/>
==Industrial development==
During the years following [[World War II]], Ferré grew his wealth by purchasing bankrupt glass, cement, and carton factories. At one point, his family empire owned 80 corporations in Puerto Rico, the United States, Venezuela, and Panama.<ref name="Sarasota">{{cite news | newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune | title=Jose Antonio Ferre Aguayo | date=19 September 1990}}</ref>
In 1965, Ferré's real estate company, the Ferré Florida Corporation, financed the construction of the 30-story [[New World Tower]] in the [[Downtown Miami#Central business district ("Downtown")|Central Business District]] in Miami. At the time, the building, which cost $6 million to construct, stood as the tallest in Florida.<ref>{{cite news | newspaper=The New York Times | title=30-Story Miami Building Will Be Tallest in Florida | date=27 November 1963}}</ref> Its construction represented part of a broader effort to revitalize Miami.<ref>{{cite news | newspaper=The New York Times | title=MIAMI REVERSES TREND OF DOWNTOWN DECAY; Enormous Project | date=November 3, 1987}}</ref>
==Legacy==
In 1990, U.S. Representative [[Ileana Ros-Lehtinen]] from [[Florida's 27th congressional district]] honored the legacy and impact of Ferré during remarks on the floor of the [[U.S. House of Representatives]]. The tribute recognized Ferré's vision and industrial pursuits.<ref name="congressional record"/>
==References==

{{notability|date=August 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = Jubilee Capital Management | logo = | type = Private | founded = 2015 | founders = Stanley Zhang Xiangdong, Gan Fong Jek, George Gong | area_served = Global; focused on Southeast Asia, China, Australia, New Zealand, Israel and the US | industry = Venture Capital | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | location_city = | location_country = Singapore | location = | locations = | caption = | homepage = http://www.jcmvc.com | dissolved = }}
'''Jubilee Capital Management (JCM)''' is a [[Singapore]]-based [[venture capital]] firm with operations in [[Beijing]] and the [[United States|US]], and partners in [[China]], [[Asia-Pacific|Asia Pacific]], [[Europe]] and the United States.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/technology/jubilee-unveils-us100m-kitty-for-series-a-startups|title=Jubilee unveils US$100m kitty for Series A startups|last=Cheok|first=Jacquelyn|work=The Business Times|access-date=26 May 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.finsmes.com/2016/11/singapore-based-vc-firm-jubilee-capital-holds-first-close-of-tech-fund-at-30m.html|title=Singapore-based VC Firm Jubilee Capital Holds First Close of Tech Fund, at $30M|date=3 November 2016|work=FinSMEs|access-date=26 May 2017|language=en-US}}</ref>
== History & background ==
JCM was founded in 2015 by Stanley Zhang, George Gong and Gan Fong Jek to invest in companies expanding into China as well as Chinese companies looking to expand overseas and grow internationally outside their home market.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/business/companies-markets/fund-to-help-s-e-asian-start-ups-tap-china|title=Fund to help S-E Asian start-ups tap China|last=hermes|date=22 November 2016|work=The Straits Times|access-date=26 May 2017|language=en}}</ref>
Before founding JCM, Stanley Zhang was founder and chief executive officer of HiChina, which was acquired by [[Alibaba Group]] in 2013.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.zaobao.com.sg/social/crossroads/general/story20160104-566964|title=中国万网前总裁 移居本地做"天使"|date=4 January 2016|work=联合早报网|access-date=26 May 2017|language=en}}</ref> George Gong co-founded BeyondSoft, an [[enterprise software]] service provider listed on the [[Shenzhen Stock Exchange]], while Gan Fong Jek is a senior [[corporate venture capital]] and [[Mergers and acquisitions|M&A]] professional formerly from [[Temasek Holdings|Temasek]]-owned corporations and a media company in Indonesia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dealstreetasia.com/stories/singapore-based-jubilee-capital-hits-first-close-for-100-million-tech-startup-fund-57112/|title=Singapore-based Jubilee Capital hits first close for $100m tech-startup fund|website=www.dealstreetasia.com|access-date=26 May 2017}}</ref> The founders are EMBA alumni of [[Tsinghua University]].<ref name=":3" />
In 2016, the company obtained its registered fund management license from the [[Monetary Authority of Singapore]],<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://e27.co/jubilee-capital-invests-us3m-fintech-startup-latipay-20170131/|title=Fintech startup LatiPay raises US$3M from Jubilee Capital, others to expand to Singapore, US|work=e27|access-date=26 May 2017|language=en-US}}</ref> and launched a US$100 million Jubilee Tech Fund. The fund invests in post-seed to [[Series A round|Series A]]-stage [[Startup company|startups]] in the [[technology]], media and [[telecommunication]]s space in [[Southeast Asia]], China, [[Israel]] and the US, with each investment ranging between US$500,000 and US$2.5 million.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://view.inews.qq.com/a/20161226G09VCY00?refer=share_recomnews|title=南洋电商观察|website=view.inews.qq.com|access-date=26 May 2017}}</ref>
== Investments ==
JCM’s [[Portfolio company|portfolio companies]] include Start (previously PPzuche), a China-based [[Carsharing|car-sharing]] platform founded in 2012<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/business/companies-markets/singapore-start-ups-head-to-china-and-thrive|title=Singapore start-ups head to China – and thrive|last=hermes|date=4 April 2017|work=The Straits Times|access-date=26 May 2017|language=en}}</ref> and Latitude Technologies (Latipay), an Auckland-based [[E-commerce payment system|online payments]] company that enables Chinese consumers to pay for merchandise or services with [[Yuan (currency)|yuan]] and [[merchant]]s to receive payment to their local bank account in their [[local currency]].<ref name=":4" />

{{Infobox person | name = Khin Khin Myint | native_name = {{nobold|{{my|ခင်မြင့်မြင့်}}}} | native_name_lang = Burmese | other_names = | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1944 | birth_place = [[Daik-U Township]], [[Myanmar]] | death_date = 19 September 2009 (aged 65) | death_place = | nationality = Burmese | ethnicity = | education = | years_active= | party = | religion = | children = 6 | spouse = Myat Thin Aung | known_for = [[Beauty pageant]] winner | occupation = Businesswoman, philanthropist | criminal_charge = | alma_mater = | criminal_penalty = }} '''Khin Myint Myint''' ({{lang-my|ခင်မြင့်မြင့်}}; 1944–19 September 2009) was a Burmese [[beauty pageant]] winner, businesswoman and philanthropist. She was president of the Myanmar Women Entrepreneurs Association.
==Early life== Khin Myint Myint was born in the [[Daik-U Township]], [[Bago Region|Bago Division]] in 1944, and attended [[BEHS 2 Dagon|Myoma High School]], where she distinguished herself in [[throwing sports]].<ref name="MT" />
==Career== At 17, Khin Myint Myint won the Miss Burma beauty pageant in 1961 and represented her country at the [[Miss Universe 1961|Miss Universe]] event held at [[Miami Beach, Florida]]. Later she became a businessperson and established a name for herself in the food industry. Also known for her philanthropy, she reportedly donated more than 300 million [[Burmese kyat]] for humanitarian causes which earned her the ''Agga Maha Thiri Thudhamma Theingi'' title.<ref name="MT">{{cite news|author=Nyein Ei Ei Htwe|title=Former ‘Miss Burma’ winner passes away|url=https://www.mmtimes.com/national-news/6057-former-miss-burma-winner-passes-away.html|accessdate=11 November 2017|work=[[The Myanmar Times]]|date=28 September 2009}}</ref>
In 2008, Khin Myint Myint received the ASEAN Award of the [[Vietnam Chamber of Commerce and Industry]]. She was the president of Myanmar Women Entrepreneurs Association and vice-chairperson of AA Medical Products.<ref name="ICC">{{cite web|title=Vietnam chamber hosts Women’s Global Summit|url=https://iccwbo.org/media-wall/news-speeches/vietnam-chamber-hosts-womens-global-summit/|publisher=[[International Chamber of Commerce]]|accessdate=11 November 2017|date=19 June 2008}}</ref>
==Personal life== Khin Myint Myint was married to Myat Thin Aung. Together the couple had six children. She died on 19 September 2009 from a [[heart attack]]; she was 65.<ref name="MT"/>

{{Infobox person | name = Korvi Rakshand | image = Korvi Rakshand Photo.jpg | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1985|08|19|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]] | nationality = [[Bangladeshi nationality law|Bangladeshi]] | residence = [[Dhaka]], Bangladesh | alma_mater = | occupation = Founder of [[JAAGO Foundation]]
President of Volunteer for Bangladesh | parents = Nurul Akter
Mafruda Khan Erin | website = http://jaago.com.bd }} '''Korvi Rakshand''' (born August 19, 1985) is a Bangladeshi social entrepreneur. He is the founder of [[JAAGO Foundation]], a non-profit organization that works with education and youth development.{{cite web|url=http://jaago.com.bd/faq/|title=JAAGO FAQ|website=JAAGO Foundation|accessdate=2014-02-19}} JAAGO Foundation was established in April 2007. Rakshand was ranked 5th in list of top 10 inspirational [[Bangladeshis]] around the world published by [[British Bangladeshi Power & Inspiration 100]] at the British Parliament Commonwealth Room.{{cite news |title=Yunus, Jawed, Abed, Shakib on list |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/yunus-jawed-abed-shakib-on-list-9011 |newspaper=The Daily Star |date=29 January 2014}} ==Early life== Rakshand was born in Dhaka, Bangladesh, to Nurul Akhter, a businessman and Mafruda Khan, the chairman and principal of London Grace International School. He finished his schooling from [[Scholastica school]] and later from [[Mastermind School]], Dhaka. ===JAAGO Foundation=== In 2007, he created the JAAGO Foundation.{{cite web |title=JAAGO Foundation |url=http://www.jaago.com.bd/who-we-are/history/ |website=JAAGO Foundation}} With 17 students he started a free-of-cost-school in the slum area of Rayer Bazar, which now runs classes for nearly 600 students. In March 2011, JAAGO opened another school in the Karail slum area of Banani, and in September 2011 opened its first online school in Gazipur, Tongi. In May 2011, JAAGO Foundation launched its volunteer wing, Volunteer for Bangladesh. At present JAAGO has 13 schools nationwide catering to the education needs of 3000 students.{{cite web|url=http://jaago.com.bd/our-school/|title=Our Schools|publisher=JAAGO Foundation}} ===Volunteer for Bangladesh=== The volunteer wing of JAAGO Foundation, Volunteer for Bangladesh was founded in 2011. Currently, with support from U.S. Embassy in Dhaka, Volunteer for Bangladesh has successfully established 32 Volunteer Groups throughout the country. These groups independently run their own projects under the supervision of a local district board. Volunteer for Bangladesh has already created virtual branches in Australia, Canada, UK and USA. To date, above 25,000 registered volunteers are working together to bring positive changes in their communities. ==Awards and recognition== * Mosaic Award Talent 2010{{cite web |title=Mosaic Award Talent 2010 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tMG61XTik-M |publisher=JAAGO Foundation}} * Commonwealth Youth Awards 2013 {{cite web |url=http://thecommonwealth.org/media/news/commonwealth-announces-2013-youth-awards-finalists |title=Commonwealth Youth Awards Finalist |website=Commonwealth of Nations}} * Top 99 under 33 Foreign Policy Leader{{cite web|title=Top 99 under 33 Foreign Policy Leaders |url=http://www.diplomaticourier.com/lists/top-99-under-33/2013/1672-korvi-rakshand |publisher=Diplomatic Courier |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150604095658/http://diplomaticourier.com/lists/top-99-under-33/2013/1672-korvi-rakshand |archive-date= 4 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} * Top 10 Inspirational Bangladeshis around the World {{cite web |url=http://www.bbpower-inspiration.com/bbpi2014.pdf |title=Top 10 Inspirational Bangladeshis |publisher=British Bangladeshi Power 100}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rakshand, Korvi}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1985 births]] [[Category:Bangladeshi businesspeople]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of London]] [[Category:People from Dhaka]]
