Kroupa]], [[Steve DeAngelo]],{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2RrXCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA69&lpg=PA69&dq=yippie+smoke+ins&source=bl&ots=jQW9a-_Rba&sig=270dBaimXEoWlYHiZhUuqiT81TQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi7qfy0wOTWAhVQ3yYKHY2mDeM4ChDoAQhAMAY#v=onepage&q=yippie%20smoke%20ins&f=false|title=The Cannabis Manifesto: A New Paradigm for Wellness|authorlink=Steve DeAngelo|first=Steve |last=DeAngelo|publisher=[[North Atlantic Books]], Berkeley, CA|date=2015}} Dean Tuckerman, [[Dennis Peron]],{{cite web|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/smellthetruth/2012/11/15/marijuana-legalization-seeds-planted-long-ago-finally-flower/|title=Marijuana Legalization: Seeds Planted Long Ago Finally Flower|website=SFGate|first=Oscar |last=Pascual|access-date=2012-11-15}} [[Jim Fouratt]],{{cite web|url=http://www.cityartsmagazine.com/you-say-you-want-revolution/|title=Activist, individualist and entrepreneur Jerry Rubin was the quintessential American|website=City Arts Magazine|author=Thomas, Pat|access-date=29 May 2018}} Steve Wessing,{{cite web|url=https://www.tokeofthetown.com/2011/05/remembering_ben_masel_activist_changed_the_cannabi.php/|title=Remembering Ben Masel: Activist Changed The Cannabis Debate|website=Toke of the Town|author=Elliott, Steve|access-date=3 May 2011}} John Penley,{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aMOoxoWpM2o|title=FILM : John Penley is an Anarcho-Yippie - A Film by Vagabond (46 min)|publisher=AUDIO VISUAL TERRORISM|access-date=13 January 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://dlib.nyu.edu/findingaids/html/tamwag/tam_501/dscref14.html|title=Guide to the John Penley Photographs and Papers/Elmer Holmes Bobst Library|publisher=Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives (NYU)|website=[[New York University]]|access-date=24 March 2015}} and Brenton Lengel.{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2012/06/18/an_occupier_eyes_congress/|title=An Occupier Eyes Congress|first=Natasha |last=Lennard|website=Salon|access-date=2012-06-18}}{{Cite web|url=http://thefifthcolumnnews.com/2016/03/interview-with-brenton-lengel2/|title=Interview With Brenton Lengel|website=The Fifth Column|access-date=2016-04-17}} A Yippie flag was frequently seen at anti-war demonstrations. The flag had a [[Anarchist symbolism#Black flag|black background]] with a five-pointed [[red star]] in the center, and a green [[Cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] leaf superimposed over it. When asked about the Yippie flag, an anonymous Yippie identified only as "Jung" told ''The New York Times'' that "The black is for anarchy. The red star is for our [[Socialist heraldry|five point program]]. And the leaf is for marijuana, which is for getting ecologically stoned without polluting the environment."{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=znjlwbfZOTcC&pg=PA78&lpg=PA78&dq=yippie+flag+five+point&source=bl&ots=_bwqn0E1zE&sig=zPprWanO0rqy9gz7N7L0reaFgo8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDYQ6AEwA2oVChMI-avaw5KEyAIViEuSCh2PIQSX#v=onepage&q=yippie%20flag%20five%20point&f=false|title=Collision at Home Plate: The Lives of Pete Rose and Bart Giamatti|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|authorlink=James Reston Jr|first=James |last=Reston Jr|date=1 February 1997}} This flag is also mentioned in Hoffman's ''[[Steal This Book]]''.Abbie Hoffman, Steal This Book, page 73. Grove Press, 1971. Abbie Hoffman and Jerry Rubin became the most famous Yippies—and bestselling authors—in part due to publicity surrounding the five-month [[Chicago Seven]] Conspiracy trial of 1969. They both used the phrase "ideology is a brain disease" to separate the Yippies from mainstream political parties that played the game by the rules. Hoffman and Rubin were arguably the most colorful of the seven defendants accused of [[criminal conspiracy]] and [[Incitement|inciting]] to [[riot]] at the August [[1968 Democratic National Convention]]. Hoffman and Rubin used the trial as a platform for Yippie antics—at one point, they showed up in court attired in judicial robes.{{cite web|url=http://famous-trials.com/chicago8/1321-contempt|title=The Chicago Eight Trial: Selected Contempt Specifications|website=Famous Trials}} ===Origins=== [[File:Yippie poster.jpg|thumb|270px|YIP poster advertising the 1968 [[Festival of Life]].]] The term ''Yippie'' was invented by Krassner and Hoffman on New Year's Eve 1967. [[Paul Krassner]] wrote in a January 2007 article in the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'': {{quote|We needed a name to signify the radicalization of hippies, and I came up with Yippie as a label for a phenomenon that already existed, an organic coalition of [[psychedelia|psychedelic]] hippies and political activists. In the process of cross-fertilization at antiwar demonstrations, we had come to share an awareness that there was a linear connection between putting kids in prison for smoking pot in this country and burning them to death with [[napalm]] on the other side of the planet.[http://articles.latimes.com/2007/jan/28/entertainment/ca-yippies28 "'60s live again, minus the LSD"]. By [[Paul Krassner]]. January 28, 2007. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''.}} Anita Hoffman liked the word, but felt that ''[[The New York Times]]'' and other "strait-laced types" needed a more formal name to take the movement seriously. That same night she came up with Youth International Party, because it symbolized the movement and made for a good play on words.David T. Dellinger, Judy Clavir and John Spitzer, The Conspiracy Trial, page 349. Bobbs-Merrill, 1970. Along with the name Youth International Party, the organization was also simply called Yippie!, as in a shout for joy (with an exclamation mark to express exhilaration).Jonah Raskin, For the Hell of It, page 129. University of California Press, 1996. "What does Yippie! mean?" Abbie Hoffman wrote. "Energy – fun – fierceness – exclamation point!"Abbie Hoffman, Revolution For the Hell of It, page 81. Dial Press, 1968. ===First press conference=== The Yippies held their first press conference in New York at the Americana Hotel March 17, 1968, five months before the August [[1968 Democratic National Convention]] in Chicago. [[Judy Collins]] sang at the press conference.{{cite web|url=http://www.famous-trials.com/chicago8/1320-collins|title=The Chicago Eight Trial : Testimony of Judy Collins|website=Famous Trials}}[[Paul Krassner]], ''Confessions of a Raving Unconfined Nut'', p. 158.{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/now/transcript/transcript348_full.html|title=NOW with Bill Moyers (transcript dated 11-26-04)|website=PBS|access-date=2004-11-26}} The ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' reported it with an article titled: "Yipes! The Yippies Are Coming!" ==The New Nation concept== {{American socialism |Former parties}} The Yippie "New Nation" concept called for the creation of alternative, counterculture institutions: [[food co-op]]s; [[underground press|underground newspapers]] and [[zines]]; [[free clinic]]s and [[support groups]]; [[artist collective]]s; [[potlatch]]es, [[Flea Market|"swap-meets"]] and [[Give-away shop|free stores]]; [[organic farming]]/[[permaculture]]; [[pirate radio]], [[bootleg recording]] and [[public-access television]]; [[Squatting]]; [[Free school movement|free schools]]; etc. Yippies believed these cooperative institutions and a radicalized hippie culture would spread until they supplanted the existing system. Many of these ideas/practices came from other (overlapping and intermingling) counter-cultural groups such as the [[Diggers (theater)|Diggers]],{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XUikrTLOJPQC&pg=PA27&dq=yippies&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwit6IWPr_HWAhWH1CYKHS31APY4ChDoAQgnMAA#v=onepage&q=yippies&f=false|title=Anti-Disciplinary Protest: Sixties Radicalism and Postmodernism|author=Julie Stephens|publisher=Cambridge University Press|date=1998}}{{cite web|url=http://www.diggers.org/history.htm|title=A People's Hxstory of the Sixties|website=The Digger Archives}} the [[San Francisco Mime Troupe]], the [[Merry Pranksters]]/[[Deadhead]]s,Rosie McGee, "Total Environmental Theatre" in ''Grateful Dead Family Album'', p. 38-40, Time-Warner Books 1990, ed. Jerilyn Lee BrandeliusJerilyn Lee Brandelius, "Every Structure Became a Dwelling" in ''Grateful Dead Family Album'', p. 68-69, Time-Warner Books 1990, ed. Jerilyn Lee Brandelius{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0tMVBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT93&lpg=PT93&dq=yippies+deadheads&source=bl&ots=3RxPhZwVd0&sig=mepWBaty_D9SP-tVs0D-WM95KQE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiy19O26OTWAhUF2SYKHfapBLcQ6AEIRTAI#v=onepage&q=yippies%20deadheads&f=false|title=Heads: A Biography of Psychedelic America|author=Jesse Jarnow|publisher=Da Capo Press|date=2016}} the [[Hog Farm]],{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9H_ZYTUXCRIC&pg=PA288&lpg=PA288&dq=yippies+hog+farm&source=bl&ots=VXuyCISc6B&sig=ekC6IJgJntO_RpkKomX3Mzu-29A&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiEztu63ePWAhVJ7SYKHaleB_UQ6AEIRjAI#v=onepage&q=yippies%20hog%20farm&f=false|title=Wicked Messenger: Bob Dylan and the 1960s|publisher=Seven Stories Press|author=[[Mike Marqusee]]|date=2003}} the [[Rainbow Family]],{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iXOOiNycqRcC&pg=PA118&lpg=PA118&dq=yippies+rainbow+family&source=bl&ots=avAYi3hJvU&sig=PQad21hpDmgXJUiBVkNS8ht1g-g&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj0g42x2-PWAhXKzlQKHUiGDuAQ6AEINTAC#v=onepage&q=yippies%20rainbow%20family&f=false|title=People of the Rainbow: A Nomadic Utopia|author=Michael I. Niman|publisher=University of Tennessee Press, Knoxville|date=1997}} the [[Esalen Institute]],[[William Irwin Thompson]], "Going Beyond it at Big Sur" in ''At the Edge of History: Speculations on the Transformation of Culture'', p. 27-66, Harper & Row, 1971 the [[Peace and Freedom Party]], the [[White Panther Party]] and [[The Farm (Tennessee)|The Farm]]. There was much overlap, social interaction and cross-pollination within these groups and the Yippies, so there was much crossover membership,{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1978/11/11/archives/jerry-rubins-change-of-cause-from-antiwar-to-me-movement-just-mimi.html|title=Jerry Rubin's Change of Cause: From Antiwar to 'Me'|publisher=New York Times|author=Klemesrud, Judy|date=11 November 1978}} as well as similar influences and intentions.Tom Wolfe, ''[[The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test]]'', Farrar Straus Giroux, 1968Robert Stone, ''[[Prime Green: Remembering the Sixties]]'', HarperCollins Publishers, 2007 "We are a people. We are a new nation," YIP's New Nation Statement said of the burgeoning [[hippie]] movement. "We want everyone to control their own life and to care for one another ... We cannot tolerate attitudes, institutions, and machines whose purpose is the destruction of life, the accumulation of profit."The New Yippie Book Collective (eds.), Blacklisted News: Secret Histories from Chicago to 1984, page 514. Bleecker Publishing, 1983. The goal was a decentralized, collective, [[anarchism|anarchistic]] nation rooted in the borderless hippie counterculture and its communal ethos. Abbie Hoffman wrote:
We shall not defeat Amerika by organizing a political party. We shall do it by building a new nation – a nation as rugged as the marijuana leaf.Abbie Hoffman, Woodstock Nation, back cover. Vintage Books, 1969.John Anthony Moretta, ''The Hippies: A 1960s History'', p. 260. [[McFarland & Company]], Jefferson, NC. 2017. {{ISBN|978-0786499496}}
The flag for the "new nation" consisted of a black background with a red five pointed star in the center and a green marijuana leaf superimposed over it (same as the YIP flag).[http://www.fotw.net/flags/us%7Dyip.html Flags of the World – Youth International Party listing] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210053745/http://www.fotw.net/flags/us%7Dyip.html |date=February 10, 2012 }} The Chicago Museum shows a different flag for the new nation.{{cite web|url=http://blog.chicagohistory.org/index.php/2011/06/yippies-in-lincoln-park-1968/|title=Chicago History Museum - Blog » Blog Archive » Yippies in Lincoln Park, 1968|publisher=|accessdate=February 4, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304073042/http://blog.chicagohistory.org/index.php/2011/06/yippies-in-lincoln-park-1968/|archivedate=March 4, 2016|df=mdy-all}} It is not the marijuana leaf. It has the word NOW under what looks like the all-seeing eye on a pyramid seen on the back of a dollar bill. ==Culture and activism== {{See also|Counterculture of the 1960s}} The Yippies often paid tribute to [[rock 'n' roll]] and irreverent pop-culture figures such as the [[Marx Brothers]], [[James Dean]] and [[Lenny Bruce]]. Many Yippies used nicknames which contained [[Baby Boomer]] television or pop references, such as [[Pogo (comics)|Pogo]] or [[Gumby]]. (Pogo was notable for creating the famous slogan: "[[Pogo_(comic_strip)#.22We_have_met_the_enemy_and_he_is_us..22|We have met the enemy and he is us]]"—first used on a 1970 [[Earth Day]] poster.) The Yippies' love of pop-culture was one way to differentiate the Old and New Left, as [[Jesse Walker]] writes in [[Reason (magazine)|Reason]] magazine: {{quote|Forty years ago, the yippies seemed unusual because they fused the political radicalism of the New Left with the long-haired, grass-smoking lifestyle of the counterculture. Today that combination is so familiar that many people don't even realize that the protesters and the hippies initially distrusted each other. What seems most curious about the yippies ''today'' is the way they mixed hard left politics with a deep appreciation for pop culture. Abbie Hoffman announced that he wanted to combine the styles of [[Andy Warhol]] and [[Fidel Castro]]. Jerry Rubin dedicated ''Do it!'' not just to his girlfriend but to "Dope, Color TV, and Violent Revolution." Even when praising a form of mass culture that had earned some grudging respect from the late-'60s left—rock 'n' roll—Rubin's list of musicians who "gave us the life/beat and set us free" included not just raucous originals like [[Jerry Lee Lewis]] and [[Bo Diddley]] but [[Fabian Forte|Fabian]] and [[Frankie Avalon]], commercial confections that most lefty rock intellectuals disdained as insufficiently authentic. In one chapter, Rubin complained that if "the white ideological left" took over, "Rock dancing would be taboo, and miniskirts, Hollywood movies and comic books would be illegal." All this from a self-proclaimed communist whose heroes included Castro, [[Chairman Mao]], and [[Ho Chi Minh]]. It's not that the yippies swallowed pop culture uncritically. (Hoffman kept a sign attached to the bottom of his TV that said "bullshit.") It's that they saw the mass media's dream-world as another terrain to fight in.{{cite web|url=http://reason.com/archives/2008/08/27/the-yippie-show|title=The Yippie Show|author=Walker, Jesse|website=REASON|access-date=27 August 2008}}}} At demonstrations and parades, Yippies often wore [[face paint]] or colorful [[bandanna]]s to keep from being identified in photographs. Other Yippies reveled in the spotlight, allowing their stealthier comrades the anonymity they needed for their pranks.{{Cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/independentlens/chicago10/yippies.html |title=CHICAGO 10: The Film: The Players: The Yippies |publisher=PBS|date=22 October 2008}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8VMEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA38-IA2&dq=yippies&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiywOXPs_HWAhUBxmMKHSFMALc4FBDoAQg-MAQ#v=onepage&q=yippies&f=false|title=The Loony Humor of the Yippies|author=[[Shana Alexander]]|publisher=LIFE magazine|date=25 October 1968}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Aim_-KChqLgC&pg=PA35&dq=yippies&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi985mv24LXAhUF5CYKHXVhD904FBDoAQhKMAY#v=onepage&q=yippies&f=false|title=Play, Creativity, and Social Movements: If I Can't Dance, It's Not My Revolution|author=Benjamin Shepard|publisher=[[Routledge]]|date=2012}} One cultural intervention that misfired was at [[Woodstock Festival|Woodstock]], with [[Abbie Hoffman]] interrupting a performance by [[The Who]], trying to speak against the incarceration of [[John Sinclair (poet)|John Sinclair]], sentenced to 10 years in prison in 1969 after giving two joints to an undercover narcotics officer. Guitarist [[Pete Townshend]] used his guitar to bat Hoffman off the stage.{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B_xR__PLTyY|title=the who - woodstock incident with abbie hoffman and pete|date=June 13, 2008|publisher=|accessdate=February 4, 2016|via=YouTube}} The Yippies were the first on the [[New Left]] to make a point of exploiting mass media.Abbie Hoffman, Soon to be a Major Motion Picture, p. 86. Perigee Books, 1980. Colorful, theatrical Yippie actions were tailored to attract media coverage and also to provide a stage where people could express the "repressed" Yippie inside them.Jerry Rubin, ''Do It!'', page 86. Simon and Schuster, 1970. "We believe every nonyippie is a repressed yippie," Jerry Rubin wrote in ''Do it!'' "We try to bring out the yippie in everybody." ===Early Yippie actions=== [[File:Yippie! Button at the Chicago History Museum.jpg|thumb|right|200px|a Yippie! button on display at the [[Chicago History Museum]]]] Yippies were famous for their sense of humor.Joseph Boskin, Rebellious Laughter: People's humor in America, page 98. Syracuse University Press, 1997. Many [[direct action]]s were often satirical and elaborate [[practical joke|prank]]s or put-ons.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yui4BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA32&dq=yippies&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi74KnE_r3cAhVFba0KHUArA6s4KBDoAQhUMAg#v=snippet&q=yippies%20&f=false|title=Radical Theatrics: Put-Ons, Politics, and the Sixties|publisher=[[University of Washington Press]]|author=Craig J. Peariso|access-date=19 July 2016|ISBN=9780295995588}} An application to levitate [[The Pentagon]]{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,841090-9,00.html|title=Protest: The Banners of Dissent|date=Oct 27, 1967|work=TIME|page=9|accessdate=December 26, 2009}}{{cite web|url=https://wagingnonviolence.org/feature/the-day-they-levitated-the-pentagon/|title=The Day they Levitated the Pentagon|website=Waging NonViolence|author=Bloch, Nadine|access-date=2012-10-21}} during the October, [[National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam|1967 March on the Pentagon]], and a mass protest/mock levitation at the building organized by Rubin, Hoffman and company at the event, helped to set the tone for Yippie when it was established a couple of months later.Jonah Raskin, For the hell of it: The life and times of Abbie Hoffman, Page 117, University of California Press, 1996 Another famous prank just before Yippie was coined was a [[guerrilla theater]] event in New York City on August 24, 1967. [[Abbie Hoffman]] and a group of future Yippies managed to get into a tour of the [[New York Stock Exchange]], where they threw fistfuls of real and fake US$ from the balcony of the visitors' gallery down to the [[trader (finance)|trader]]s below, some of whom booed, while others began to scramble frantically to grab the money as fast as they could. Soon To Be A Major Motion Picture: The Autobiography of Abbie Hoffman, First Edition, Perigree Books, 1980, p. 101. The visitors' gallery was closed until a glass barrier could be installed, to prevent similar incidents. On the 40th anniversary of the NYSE event, [[CNN]]-Money editor James Ledbetter described the now-famous incident: {{quote|[The] group of pranksters began throwing handfuls of one-dollar bills over the railing, laughing the entire time. (The exact number of bills is a matter of dispute; Hoffman later wrote that it was 300, while others said no more than 30 or 40 were thrown.) Some of the brokers, clerks and stock runners below laughed and waved; others jeered angrily and shook their fists. The bills barely had time to land on the ground before guards began removing the group from the building, but news photos had been taken and the Stock Exchange "happening" quickly slid into iconic status. Once outside, the activists formed a circle, holding hands and chanting "Free! Free!" At one point, Hoffman stood in the center of the circle and lit the edge of a $5 bill while grinning madly, but an NYSE runner grabbed it from him, stamped on it, and said: "You're disgusting." If the prank accomplished nothing else, it helped cement Hoffman's reputation as one of America's most outlandish and creative protestors ... the "Yippie" movement quickly became a prominent part of America's counterculture.{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2007/07/17/news/funny/abbie_hoffman/|title=The day the NYSE went Yippie|website=CNN Money|author=Ledbetter, James|access-date=23 August 2007}}}} There was a clash with police on March 22, 1968, where a large group of countercultural youths led by the Yippies descended into [[Grand Central Terminal|Grand Central Station]] for a "Yip-In".{{cite web|url=https://repositories.lib.utexas.edu/handle/2152/17999/|title=Radical Street Theatre and the Yippie Legacy: a Performance History of the Youth International Party, 1967-1968|author=Susanne E. Shawyer|website=University of Texas, Austin|date=May 2008}} The night erupted into a violent clash with police that Don McNeill of ''[[The Village Voice]]'' christened a "pointless confrontation in a [[box canyon]]".{{cite book|last=Gitlin|first=Todd|title=The Sixties: Years of Hope, Days of Rage|location=New York|year=1993|pages=238}}{{cite web|url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2010/04/21/nat-hentoff-on-the-police-riot-against-yippies-at-grand-central/|author=Hentoff, Nat|website=The Village Voice|title=Nat Hentoff on the Police Riot Against Yippies at Grand Central (4 April 1968)|access-date=21 April 2010}} A month after the Grand Central Station Yip-In, Yippies organized a "Yip-Out," a be-in style event in Central Park that went off peacefully and drew 20,000 people.Neil Hamilton, The ABC-CLIO companion to the 1960s counterculture in America, Page 340, ABC-CLIO, 1997. In his book ''A Trumpet to Arms: Alternative Media in America'', author David Armstrong points out that the Yippie hybrid of [[performance art]], [[Guerilla theatre]] and political irreverence was often in direct conflict with the sensibility of the 60s American Left/peace movement:
The Yippies' unorthodox approach to revolution, which emphasized spontaneity over structure, and media blitz over community organizing, put them almost as much at odds with the rest of the left as with mainstream culture. Wrote (Jerry) Rubin in the ''[[Berkeley Barb]]'', "The worst thing you can say about a demonstration is that it is boring, and one of the reasons that the peace movement has not grown into a mass movement is that the peace movement--its literature and its events--is a bore. Good theatre is needed to communicate revolutionary content.David Armstrong, ''A Trumpet to Arms: Alternative Media in America'', p. 120-121, [[South End Press]], Boston. 1981
===House Un-American Activities Committee=== The [[House Un-American Activities Committee]] (HUAC) subpoenaed [[Jerry Rubin]] and [[Abbie Hoffman]] of the Yippies in 1967, and again in the aftermath of the [[1968 Democratic National Convention]]. The Yippies used media attention to make a mockery of the proceedings: Rubin came to one session dressed as an [[American Revolutionary War]] soldier, and passed out copies of the [[United States Declaration of Independence]] to people in attendance. Then Rubin "blew giant gum bubbles while his co-witnesses taunted the committee with [[Nazi]] salutes".[http://www.bookrags.com/Youth_International_Party Youth International Party], 1992. Rubin also attended HUAC dressed as [[Santa Claus]] and a [[Viet Cong]] soldier. On another occasion, police stopped Hoffman at the building entrance and arrested him for wearing an [[American flag]]. Hoffman quipped for the press, "I regret that I have but one shirt to give for my country", paraphrasing the last words of revolutionary patriot [[Nathan Hale]]; meanwhile Rubin, who was wearing a matching [[Viet Cong]] flag, shouted that the police were Communists for not arresting him also.Jerry Rubin, ''[http://faculty.atu.edu/cbrucker/Amst2003/Texts/Yippie.pdf A Yippie Manifesto]''. According to ''[[The Harvard Crimson]]'':
In the fifties, the most effective sanction was terror. Almost any publicity from HUAC meant the '[[Hollywood blacklist|blacklist]].' Without a chance to clear his name, a witness would suddenly find himself without friends and without a job. But it is not easy to see how in 1969 a HUAC blacklist could terrorize an [[Students for a Democratic Society (1960 organization)|SDS]] activist. Witnesses like Jerry Rubin have openly boasted of their contempt for American institutions. A [[subpoena]] from HUAC would be unlikely to scandalize Abbie Hoffman or his friends.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1969/2/24/by-any-other-name-pthe-house|title=By Any Other Name. Brass Tacks.|author=GEOGHEGAN, THOMAS|publisher=The Harvard Crimson|date=24 February 1969}}
==Chicago '68== {{See also|1968 Democratic National Convention protest activity}} [[File:August 25, 1968, Hippies in Lincoln Park, Chicago.webm|thumb|right|300px|thumbtime=3:58|Anti-war demonstrators in [[Lincoln Park, Chicago]], attending a [[Yippie]] organized event, approximately five miles north of the convention center. The band [[MC5]] can be seen playing.]] Yippie theatrics culminated at the [[1968 Democratic National Convention]] in Chicago. YIP planned a six-day Festival of Life – a celebration of the [[counterculture]] and a protest against the state of the nation.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QUAeoaEbzPkC&pg=PA12&dq=yippies&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiordfytfHWAhVK42MKHWNPCwY4HhDoAQhHMAU#v=onepage&q=yippies&f=false|title=1968: Art and Politics in Chicago|publisher=DePaul University Art Museum|editor=Patricia Kelly|date=2008}} This was supposed to counter the "Convention of Death." This promised to be "the blending of pot and politics into a political grass leaves movement – a cross-fertilization of the hippie and [[New Left]] philosophies."{{cite web|url=http://www.grin.com/en/e-book/324245/democracy-in-america-yippie-guerilla-theater-and-the-reinvigoration-of|title=Democracy in America, Yippie! Guerilla Theater and the Reinvigoration of the American Democratic Process During the Cold War|publisher=Syracuse University|author=Kayla Schultz|date=2008}} Yippies' sensational statements before the convention were part of the theatrics, including a [[tongue-in-cheek]] threat to put [[LSD]] in Chicago's water supply. "We will fuck on the beaches! ... We demand the Politics of Ecstasy! ... Abandon the Creeping Meatball! ... And all the time 'Yippie! Chicago – August 25–30.'" First on a list of Yippie demands: "An immediate end to the war in Vietnam."Norman Mailer, ''[[Miami and the Siege of Chicago]],'' page 137. Signet Books, 1968.{{cite web|url=https://www.nonviolent-conflict.org/the-us-anti-vietnam-war-movement-1964-1973/|website=International Center on Nonviolent Conflict (ICNC)|title=The US Anti-Vietnam War Movement (1964-1973)|author=Stephen Zunes, Jesse Laird|date=January 2010}} Yippie organizers hoped that well-known musicians would participate in the [[1968 Democratic National Convention protest activity|Festival of Life]] and draw a crowd of tens if not hundreds of thousands from across the country. The city of Chicago refused to issue any permits for the festival and most musicians withdrew from the project. Of the rock bands who had agreed to perform, only the [[MC5]] came to Chicago to play and their set was cut short by a clash between the audience of a couple thousand and police. [[Phil Ochs]] and several other singer-songwriters also performed during the festival.David Farber, Chicago '68, page 177-8, University of Chicago Press, 1988. In response to the Festival of Life and other [[anti-war]] demonstrations during the [[1968 Democratic National Convention|Democratic convention]], Chicago police repeatedly clashed with protesters, as many millions of viewers watched the extensive TV coverage of the events. On the evening of August 28 the police attacked the protesters in front of the Conrad Hilton hotel as the demonstrators chant "[[The whole world is watching]]".{{cite book|last=Miller|first=James|title=Democracy is in the Streets: From Port Huron to the Siege of Chicago|publisher=Simon & Schuster|location=New York|year=1987|pages=304}} This was a "police riot," concluded the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence,The Walker Report, ''Rights in Conflict: The violent confrontation between demonstrators and police in the parks and streets of Chicago during the week of the Democratic National Convention'', p. 5, Bantam Books, 1968. saying "On the part of the police there was enough wild club swinging, enough cries of hatred, enough gratuitous beating to make the conclusion inescapable that individual policemen, and lots of them, committed violent acts far in excess of the requisite force for crowd dispersal or arrest." ===The conspiracy trial=== {{See also|Chicago Seven}} Following the convention, eight protesters were charged with conspiracy to incite the riots, and there was a heavily publicized, five-month trial. The [[Chicago Seven]] represented a cross-section of the New Left, including [[Abbie Hoffman]] and [[Jerry Rubin]].{{cite web|url=https://www.gq.com/story/the-mess-we-made|title=The Mess We Made: An Oral History of the '68 Convention|website=GQ.com|author=Goldstein, Sarah|access-date=2008-08-12}} In his book, ''American Fun: Four Centuries of Joyous Revolt'', John Beckman writes:
''Never mind ''[[Hair (musical)|Hair]]'', the so-called Chicago Eight (then Seven) trial was the countercultural performance of the sixties. [[Guerrilla theater]] stared down courtroom farce to decide the civil dispute of the era: the Movement vs. the Establishment. The eight defendants seemed finically chosen to represent the world of dissent: [[Students for a Democratic Society|SDS]] leaders [[Rennie Davis]] and [[Tom Hayden]] (who had authored "The [[Port Huron Statement]]"); graduate students [[Lee Weiner]] and [[John Froines]]; portly fifty-four-year-old Christian socialist [[David Dellinger]]; Yippies Rubin and Hoffman; and--briefly--[[Black Panther Party|Black Panther]] [[Bobby Seale]]. "Conspire, hell," Hoffman quipped. "We couldn't agree on lunch."{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9ahdAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT290&dq=john+beckman+froines+yippies&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjp69GhkazbAhWdnoMKHR0FDmoQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=john%20beckman%20froines%20yippies&f=false|title=American Fun: Four Centuries of Joyous Revolt|author=John Beckman|publisher=[[Pantheon Books]], New York|date=2014|ISBN=978-0-307-90818-6}}
Several other Yippies – including [[Stew Albert]], Wolfe Lowenthal, Brad Fox and Robin Palmer – were among another 18 activists named as "unindicted co-conspirators" in the case.David T. Dellinger, Judy Clavir and John Spitzer, The Conspiracy Trial, page 601. Bobbs-Merrill, 1970. While five of the defendants were initially convicted of crossing state lines to incite a riot, all convictions were soon reversed in appeal court. Defendants Hoffman and Rubin became popular authors and public speakers, spreading Yippie militancy and comedy wherever they appeared. When Hoffman appeared on ''[[The Merv Griffin Show]]'', for example, he wore a shirt with an American flag design, prompting [[CBS]] to black out his image when the show aired.Abbie Hoffman, Soon to be a Major Motion Picture, page 170. Perigee Books, 1980. ==The Yippie movement== The Youth International Party quickly spread beyond Rubin, Hoffman and the other founders. YIP had chapters all over the US and in other countries, with particularly active groups in New York City, [[Vancouver]], [[Washington, D.C.]], Detroit, [[Milwaukee]], Los Angeles, [[Tucson]], [[Houston]], [[Austin]], [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]], [[Dayton]], Chicago, [[Berkeley California|Berkeley]], [[San Francisco]] and [[Madison, Wisconsin|Madison]].Ken Wachsberger, ''The Ballad of Ken and Emily, or, Tales from the Counterculture'', Page 54, Azenphony Press, 1997 There were YIP conferences through the 1970s, beginning with a "New Nation Conference" in Madison, Wisconsin in 1971.The New Yippie Book Collective, ''Blacklisted News: Secret Histories from Chicago to 1984'', Page 16. Bleecker Publishing, 1983. ===Street protests=== On the final day of the Madison conference, April 4, 1971, hundreds of riot police broke up a block party organized by local Yippies to cap the event, resulting in a street clash between Yippies and police."Yippies Pelt Police with Eggs, Rocks." April 5, 1971, ''The Rock Hill Herald''. During an anti-war protest in Washington, D.C., on November 15, 1969, East Coast Yippies led thousands of youths in the storming of the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] building.Kifner, John. "Tear Gas Repels Radicals' Attack." ''New York Times'', 16 November 1969 On August 6, 1970, L.A. Yippies invaded [[Disneyland]], hoisting the New Nation flag at City Hall and taking over [[Tom Sawyer's Island]]. While riot police confronted the Yippies, the theme park was closed early for only the second time in the park's history (the first being shortly after the [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|assassination of President Kennedy]].{{cite book|title=Blacklisted News: Secret Histories from Chicago to 1984|editor=The New Yippie Book Collective|publisher=Bleecker Publishing|year=1983|pages=459}}). As many as 23 of the 200 Yippies attending were arrested.{{cite web|url=http://nightflight.com/august-6-1970-the-day-the-yippies-invaded-disneyland/|title=August 6, 1970, the Day the Yippies invaded Disneyland|website=NightFlight|author=Thomas, Bryan|access-date=2015-08-06}} Vancouver Yippies invaded the U.S. border town of [[Blaine, Washington]], on May 9, 1970, to protest [[Richard Nixon]]'s [[Cambodian Campaign|invasion of Cambodia]] and [[Kent State shooting|the shooting of students]] at [[Kent State]].{{cite book|title=Blacklisted News: Secret Histories from Chicago to 1984|editor=The New Yippie Book Collective|publisher=Bleecker Publishing|year=1983|pages=457}} Columbus Yippies were charged with inciting the rioting that occurred in the city on May 11, 1972, in response to Nixon's mining of North Vietnam's Haiphong harbor.{{cite book|title=Blacklisted News: Secret Histories from Chicago to 1984|editor=The New Yippie Book Collective|publisher=Bleecker Publishing|year=1983|pages=403}} They were acquitted. YIP was a member of the coalition of anti-Vietnam War activists who, over several days in early May 1971, tried to shut down the U.S. government by occupying intersections and bridges in Washington, D.C. The [[1971 May Day Protests|May Day protests]] resulted in the largest [[mass arrest]] in American history.Lester Friedman, American cinema of the 1970s: themes and variations, Page 49, NJ Rutgers University Press, 2007{{cite web|url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/1971/06/17/a-special-supplement-mayday-the-case-for-civil-dis/|title=Mayday: The Case for Civil Disobedience|author=Chomsky, Noam|publisher=[[The New York Review of Books]]|date=17 June 1971}} A frequent 'national' complaint among Yippies was that the New York 'central HQ' chapter acted as if other chapters did not exist and kept them out of the decision-making process. At one point, at a YIP conference in Ohio in 1972, Yippies voted to 'exclude' Abbie and Jerry as official spokespersons from the party, since they had become too famous and rich.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1972/11/28/archives/yippies-exclude-hoffman-and-rubin-as-spokesmen.html|title=Yippies Exclude Hoffman And Rubin as Spokesmen|website=New York Times|date=28 November 1972}} In 1972, Yippies and [[Zippie]]s (a younger YIP radical breakaway faction whose "guiding spirit" was [[Tom Forcade]]){{cite web|url=http://thevillager.com/2018/02/25/yippies-vs-zippies-new-jerry-rubin-book-reveals-70s-counterculture-feud/|title=Yippies vs. Zippies: New Rubin book reveals '70s counterculture feud|author=Reinholz, Mary|website=[[The Villager (Manhattan)|''The Villager'']]|access-date=25 February 2018}} staged protests at the [[1972 Republican National Convention|Republican]] and [[1972 Democratic National Convention|Democratic Convention]]s in [[Miami Beach]].The New Yippie Book Collective (eds.), ''Blacklisted News: Secret Histories from Chicago to 1984'', page 354. Bleecker Publishing, 1983.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FrEqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=k2YEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2989,3327051&dq=dana+beal&hl=en Marijuana Smoke-in Held Outside Convention Hall]. July 10, 1972. ''[[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]]''. Some of the Miami protests were larger and more militant than the ones in Chicago in 1968. After Miami, the Zippies evolved back into Yippies.Abbie Hoffman, Soon to be a Major Motion Picture, page 278. Perigee Books, 1980. [[File:PittsburghSmokeIn3.JPG|thumb|Poster advertising Yippie-sponsored Pittsburgh Smoke-In, Schenley Park, July 2, 1977]] In 1973, Yippies marched on the Manhattan home of [[Watergate]] conspirator [[John N. Mitchell|John Mitchell]]:
... five hundred die-hard Yippies staged one last march on the Mitchell home, no longer the Watergate but a grand apartment building on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue. "Free [[Martha Mitchell]]!" they chanted. "Fuck John!" When the Mitchells finally appeared at the window to see what all the commotion was about, the stoners cherished their last "eye-to-eyeball confrontation with Mr. Law 'n' Order." To commemorate the moment, they placed a giant marijuana joint on the Mitchells' doorstep.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fHIGQTGemnAC&pg=PA113&lpg=PA113&dq=steve+conliff+yippies&source=bl&ots=Rx-qLBpdiM&sig=eZB6Dk5Kj4OWr_2jFSZnAVYbrzI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj1ovjy8-7WAhUG6CYKHeXdAOs4ChDoAQgvMAI#v=onepage&q=steve%20conliff%20yippies&f=false|title=The Strong Man: John Mitchell and the Secrets of Watergate|author=[[James Rosen (journalist)|James Rosen]]|publisher=Doubleday|date=2008}}
Yippies regularly protested at [[United States presidential inauguration|US presidential inauguration]]s,{{cite web|url=https://crimethinc.com/2017/01/16/whoever-they-vote-for-we-are-ungovernable-a-history-of-anarchist-counter-inaugural-protest|title=Whoever They Vote For, We Are Ungovernable: A History of Anarchist Counter-Inaugural Protest|author=CrimethInc, Ex-Workers Collective|website=CrimethInc|access-date=16 January 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1981/1/21/amid-washingtons-pomp-a-counter-inaugural-pwashington-less/|title=Amid Washington's Pomp, a 'Counter-Inaugural'|website=The Harvard Crimson|author=Cooperman, Alan|date=21 January 1981}}{{cite web|url=https://pictures.abebooks.com/BLOLBC/md/md22649082422.jpg|title=POSTER: Counter-Inaugural Ball & Protests|publisher=Youth International Party|website=AbeBooks.com|date=1981}} with a particularly strong presence at the 1973 inauguration of [[Richard Nixon]]. Yippies also demonstrated at the [[1980 Republican National Convention]] in Detroit,{{cite web|url=https://quod.lib.umich.edu/s/scl/x-lpf.1566/LPF1566?auth=scl;g=um-ic;lasttype=boolean;lastview=reslist;resnum=17;size=50;sort=scl_wt;start=1;subview=detail;view=entry;rgn1=ic_all;q1=scl|title=PHOTO: Yippies for Reagan (Republican National Convention 1980)|author=Berry, Millard|website=[[Labadie Collection]], [[University of Michigan]]|publisher=[[Fifth Estate (periodical)|Fifth Estate]]|date=July 1980}} as well as the subsequent [[1984 Republican National Convention]] in Dallas,{{cite web|url=http://nwo.media.xs2.net/photos/index.html|title=Yippies protest President Reagan in Dallas 1984|website=Yippie archives|date=August 1984}}{{cite web|url=https://pictures.abebooks.com/BLOLBC/md/md22649082433.jpg|title=POSTER: Don't Let Reagan Take You for a Ride!|publisher=Youth International Party|website=AbeBooks.com|date=1984}} where 99 Yippies were arrested: {{quote|DALLAS, Aug 22 — Ninety-nine demonstrators were arrested today outside the Republican National Convention after a ''Corporate War Chest Tour'' through the downtown area in which they intimidated shoppers, splattered paint and burned an American flag. The demonstrators, members of the Youth International Party, or Yippies, completed the spree through downtown by jumping into the reflecting pool at City Hall in the sweltering Dallas heat.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/23/us/99-arrested-in-dallas-protest.html|title=99 ARRESTED IN DALLAS PROTEST|website=The New York Times|date=23 August 1984}}}} ===Smoke-Ins=== {{anchor|Smoke-in}} [[File:Smokeinposter.jpg|thumb|Smokeinposter|Poster advertising Yippie-sponsored Smoke-In at Ohio State University, April 29, 1978.]] Yippies organized [[marijuana]] "smoke-ins" across North America through the 1970s and into the 1980s. The first YIP smoke-in was attended by 25,000 in Washington, D.C. on July 4, 1970.{{cite book|title=Blacklisted News: Secret Histories from Chicago to 1984|editor=The New Yippie Book Collective|publisher=Bleecker Publishing|year=1983|pages=4}} There was a culture clash when many of the hippie protesters strolled en masse into the nearby "Honor America Day" festivities with Billy Graham and Bob Hope.{{cite web|url=https://cannabisparade.org/history/|title=A Brief History of the NYC Cannabis Parade|author=A. I dressed like a hippie pimp back then, because punk wasn't around yet.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nymag.com/fashion/lookbook/24358/|title=The Look Book: John Waters, Filmmaker|website=New York Magazine|author=Larocca, Amy|access-date=2007-10-25}} ===Pranking the system=== Yippies mocked the system and its authority. The Youth International Party, having nominated a pig ([[Pigasus (politics)|Pigasus]]) for U.S. president in 1968, famously ran [[Nobody for President]] as its 'official' candidate in 1976.{{cite web|url=http://www.zisman.ca/openroad/1977-Spring/pages/P25.pdf |title=Everybody needs nobody sometimes|author=Conliff, Steve|publisher=Open Road|date=Spring 1977}}*[http://www.headcount.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Nobody-for-President.jpg PHOTO: Nobody For President, Curtis Spangler and Wavy Gravy, October 12, 1976] (photo credit: James Stark) ''HeadCount.org''{{cite web|url=http://www.wholeearth.com/issue/2061/article/271/20th.anniversary.rendezvous.-.wavy.gravy|author=Wavy Gravy|title=20th Anniversary Rendezvous - Wavy Gravy|publisher=Whole Earth Review|website=WholeEarth.com|date=Winter 1988}} Vancouver Yippie Betty "Zaria" Andrew ran as the Youth International Party's candidate for mayor in 1970. One of her campaign promises was to repeal every law, including the law of gravity so that everyone could get high. That same year, Berkeley Yippie Stew Albert ran for sheriff of Alameda County, challenging the incumbent sheriff to a high-noon duel and receiving 65,000 votes.Stew Albert, Who the Hell is Stew Albert?, Page 131. Red Hen Press, 2003. In 1970, Detroit Yippies went to city hall and applied for a permit to blow up the General Motors building. After the permit was denied, the Yippies said that it just goes to show you can't work within the system to change the system. "This destroys my last hope for legal channels," said Detroit Yippie Jumpin' Jack Flash.The New Yippie Book Collective, Blacklisted News: Secret Histories from Chicago to 1984, Page 414. Bleecker Publishing, 1983. Some Yippies, including [[Robin Morgan]], [[Nancy Kurshan]], Sharon Krebs and [[Judy Gumbo]], were active in the [[Guerilla theatre]] feminist group W.I.T.C.H. ([[Women's International Terrorist Conspiracy from Hell]]), which combined "theatricality, humor, and activism."Robin Morgan, [[Sisterhood is Powerful]], page 538. Vintage Books, 1970.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6zaVkAjBuPEC&pg=PA76&lpg=PA76&dq=feminist+yippies&source=bl&ots=zOLFvoctPY&sig=cmvK-S93ZnliM4iINI17Lr3-jqc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj6lbmp3-PWAhVDwVQKHbS_BtMQ6AEISTAI#v=onepage&q=feminist%20yippies&f=false|title=Daring to be Bad: Radical Feminism in America 1967-1975|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|author=Alice Echols|date=1989}} On November 7, 1970, Jerry Rubin and London Yippies took over ''The Frost Programme'' when he was the guest on the popular British TV program. In all the chaos, a Yippie fired a water pistol into host David Frost's open mouth, the broadcaster called for a commercial break and the show was over. ''The Daily Mirror'''s banner headline: "THE FROST FREAKOUT."Jerry Rubin, ''We Are Everywhere'', Page 248, Harper and Row, 1971 ===Pie-throwing=== [[Pieing|Pie-throwing]] as a political act was invented by Yippies.Laurence Leamer, ''The Paper Revolutionaries'', page 72. Simon and Schuster, 1972. The first political pieing was carried out by Tom Forcade, when he pied a member of the [[President's Commission on Obscenity and Pornography]] in 1970.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/12/10/weekinreview/take-sugar-eggs-beliefs-and-aim.html|website=New York Times|title=Take Sugar, Eggs, Beliefs ... And Aim|author=Vinciguerra, Thomas|date=10 December 2000}} Milwaukee Yippie Pat Small was the first person to be arrested for a pieing, following a hit on a Miami alderman prior to the convention protests in 1972.The New Yippie Book Collective, Blacklisted News: Secret Histories from Chicago to 1984, Page 292. Bleecker Publishing, 1983. Columbus Yippie Steve Conliff pied Ohio Governor James Rhodes in 1977 to protest the Kent State shootings.{{cite web|url=http://www.columbusmonthly.com/lifestyle/20170815/oral-history-pieing-of-gov-jim-rhodes-at-ohio-state-fair|title=An Oral History: The pieing of Gov. Jim Rhodes at the Ohio State Fair|website=Columbus Monthly|author=Ghose, Dave|accessdate=August 15, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://bondiviewertest.azurewebsites.net/DataView/Article/HT?issueKey=19771201&articleKey=19771201178|title=Pie Times for Pols|publisher=High Times|author=Shushnick, Irving|date=December 1977}} Aron "The Pieman" Kay became the best-known Yippie pie-thrower.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PSK_l32a4NMC&printsec=frontcover&dq=google+books+yippies+pieman&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiI3LW7isvYAhWi44MKHfx0A6UQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Pie Any Means Necessary: The Biotic Baking Brigade Cookbook|publisher=[[AK Press]], Oakland, CA|page=15|date=2004|author=Biotic Baking Brigade}}{{cite web|url=http://gallery.98bowery.com/pie-assassin-invitations/|title=Pie Assassin Aron Kay - Two nightclub events honoring Yippie pie man, 1990|website=GALLERY 98|date=1990}} Kay's many targets included Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan hit with pie by Aron Kay, 1976] Photo from Associated Press New York City Mayor [[Abraham Beame|Abe Beame]],{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1977/09/01/two-pie-tuesday/7ce9259d-8681-4717-b376-a3fd5f621824/|website=Washington Post|title=Two-Pie Tuesday|author=Michael Kernan, William Gildea|date=1 September 1977}} conservative activist [[Phyllis Schlafly]],{{cite web|url=http://www.apimages.com/metadata/Index/Watchf-AP-A-NY-USA-APHS262270-Phyllis-Schlafly-/e5ad423b720d40598e5d427051affa5f|title=PHYLLIS SCHLAFLY ERA OPPOSITION - ARON KAY HOLDING PIE (photo)|publisher=Associated Press|website=AP Images|date=16 April 1977}}[[Watergate]] burglar [[Frank Sturgis]],{{cite web|url=http://www.apimages.com/metadata/Index/Associated-Press-Domestic-News-New-York-United-/50a5c1f343e5da11af9f0014c2589dfb/10/0|title=PIE THROWER|publisher=Associated Press|website=AP Images|date=3 November 1977}} ex-[[CIA]] head [[William Colby]], [[National Review]] publisher/editor [[William F. Buckley]],The New Yippie Book Collective (eds.), ''Blacklisted News: Secret Histories from Chicago to 1984'', page 288. Bleecker Publishing, 1983. and notorious [[Studio 54]] disco-owner and tax-evader, [[Steve Rubell]].{{cite web|url=http://nostos1.rssing.com/browser.php?indx=6246948&item=13601|website=Nostos-Music.blogspot|title=22 photos that show the grit and the glamour of Studio 54, New York City's most infamous club|access-date=September 24, 2016}} Kay's flamboyant 1979 attempt to pie [[Elvis Costello]] (for racist comments made to [[Bonnie Bramlett]] and [[Stephen Stills]] in a Columbus, Ohio [[Holiday Inn]] bar, earlier that year) was thwarted by security at the Manhattan punk nightclub ''Great Gildersleeves.''{{cite web|url=http://www.elviscostello.info/wiki/index.php/Overthrow,_May_1979|publisher=OVERTHROW|date=May 1979|author=Spy Smasher (Steve Conliff)|title=The 'Big El' Controversy : What's So Funny Bout Niggers, Limeys and Misunderstanding?|website=ElvisCostello.info.wiki}} ===Nobody for President and "None of the Above"=== ''See also:'' ''[[Nobody for President]]'' ''and'' ''[[None of the Above]]'' Perhaps one of the swan songs of [[Yippies]] was a groundbreaking effort to place a new voting option, [[None of the Above]], on the election ballot in [[Santa Barbara County]], in California, by the [[Isla Vista Municipal Advisory Council]] in 1976. This represented an incipient libertarian impulse of Yippies and the first example in the United States of this election ballot alternative, in what one of the resolution's two co-sponsors, [[Matthew Steen]], described as an "anti-institutional [[Yippie]] up-yours." Years earlier Steen had been a Yippie activist with [[Stew Albert]], as a reporter with the ''[[Berkeley Tribe]]''. This novel motion was adopted unanimously by the Council, having a ripple effect across the country, with voters in [[Nevada]] approving this option in a change to state election laws in 1986.{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/10/none-of-the-above-ballot_n_3576469.html|title='None Of The Above' Ballot Option In Nevada Upheld By Federal Appeals Court|date=2015-11-25|access-date=2016-08-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125044018/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/10/none-of-the-above-ballot_n_3576469.html|archivedate=November 25, 2015|df=mdy-all}} And in 2000 a citizen initiative to place [[None of the Above]] on the official state ballot in California was qualified although the proposition was voted down 62% to 38% in the general election that year. The most recent addition, internationally, are for state elections in [[India]] where this option must be made available in [[electronic voting machines]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/326064958/Negative-Voting-in-the-Indian-Election-System-A-Study|title="Negative Voting in the Indian Election System- A Study" by Prethin V. Pothen|publisher=University of Madras|access-date=2014-01-04}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/8249541/_A_Paradox_of_Right_to_Recall_and_Reject_-_A_boon_or_bane_ |title="A Paradox of Right to Recall and Reject - A boon or bane" by Sanjeev Chaswal|publisher=Institute of Constitutional and Parliamentary Studies, New Delhi}} In 1976, national Yippies took a cue from [[Isla Vista]]ns, backing [[Nobody for President]], a campaign that took on a life of its own in the post-Watergate malaise of the mid-70s. The Yippie campaign slogan: "Nobody's perfect."The New Yippie Book Collective, Blacklisted News: Secret Histories from Chicago to 1984, Page 321. Bleecker Publishing, 1983. (Meanwhile, in a strange twist of Yippie fate, [[Matthew Steen]] had become treasurer of a student-led campaign to elect [[Jerry Brown]] for President, competing against both "Nobody for President" and [[Jimmy Carter]] during the presidential primary campaign of that year.) From the experimental combination of Isla Vista local politics, presidential campaigns and the Yippies, the name and spirit of this unexpected ballot initiative spread quickly—in the form of [[None of the Above]] music festivals, radio and television shows, rock bands, T-shirts, buttons, (decades later) countless websites and other related social phenomena. The die-hard dedication to the 'option' of [[Nobody for President]] and [[None of the Above]] has not abated since the counter-cultural 70s, but has only grown, unexpectedly taking the Yippie legacy into a new century and succeeding generations.{{cite web|url=http://hoaxes.org/archive/permalink/nobody_for_president/|title=Nobody For President|website=hoaxes.org|accessdate=September 16, 2017}}[http://www.nobodyforpresident.org/index2020.html Nobody for President 2020][[File:Freetheweed.jpg|thumb|Freetheweed|Banner at Halloween Yippie Smoke-In, Columbus, Ohio, 1978]] ==Writings== "An exegesis on women's liberation" by the Women's Caucus within the Youth International Party was included in the 1970 anthology ''[[Sisterhood is Powerful]]: An Anthology of Writings From The Women's Liberation Movement'', edited by [[Robin Morgan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/sisterhood-is-powerful-an-anthology-of-writings-from-the-womens-liberation-movement/oclc/96157 |title=Sisterhood is powerful : an anthology of writings from the women's liberation movement (Book, 1970) |publisher=[WorldCat.org] |date= |accessdate=2015-05-08}} In June 1971 Abbie Hoffman and Al Bell started the pioneer [[phreaking|phreak]] magazine ''The Youth International Party Line'' (''YIPL''). Lee|publisher=Simon & Schuster|date=2012}} The most famous writing to come out of the Yippie movement is [[Abbie Hoffman]]'s ''[[Steal This Book]]'', which is considered to be a guidebook in causing general mischief and capturing the spirit of the Yippie movement. Hoffman is also the author of ''Revolution for the Hell of It'' which has been called the original Yippie book. This book claims that there were no actual yippies, and that the name was just a term used to create a myth.{{cite book|title=The Sixties Papers: Documents of a Rebellious Decade|editor1=Judith Clavir Albert |editor2=Stewart Edward Albert |location=Connecticut|year=1984|pages=402}} Jerry Rubin published his account of the Yippie movement in his book ''Do IT!: Scenarios of Revolution.''{{Cite web|url=http://www.enotes.com/topics/do-scenarios-revolution |title=Rubin, Jerry: Do IT! ''[[Buy This Too]]'' (Wagner, Minne HA! HA!/Brain Trust, 1987) recounted efforts by the guerrilla street theater gang, the 1985 Brain Trust, a group inspired by a series of meetings and interviews between Wagner and Krassner in May 1981, when Krassner was in Minneapolis to perform standup comedy at Dudley Riggs ETC Theater, to fight the New Right with Yippie-like myth-making tactics in the Midwest during the early 1980s.''Buy This Too'', by Pete Wagner, Minne HA! HA! Publishing, Minneapolis 1987 In 1983, a group of Yippies published ''[[Blacklisted News: Secret Histories from Chicago, '68 to 1984]]'' (Bleecker Publishing), a large, 'phone-book sized anthology' (733 pages) of Yippie history, including journalistic accounts from both alternative and mainstream media, as well as many personal stories and essays. Includes countless photographs, old leaflets and posters, 'underground' comics, newspaper clippings, and various other historical ephemera. The editors (often doubling as authors) officially called themselves "The New Yippie Book Collective"; which included [[Steve Conliff]] (who wrote over half the volume), [[Dana Beal]] (head archivist), Grace Nichols, Daisy Deadhead, [[Ben Masel]], Alice Torbush, Karen Wachsman, and Aron Kay.{{Cite book|title=Blacklisted News: Secret Histories from Chicago, '68, to 1984 | author=New Yippie Book Collective | isbn=9780912873008 |publisher=Bleecker Publishing|date=1983}} It is still in print. Vancouver Yippie Bob Sarti's play ''Yippies in Love'', premiered in June 2011.{{cite news|last1=Hawthorn|first1=Tom| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/tom-hawthorn/yippies-in-love-exploring-the-vancouver-riot---of-40-years-ago/article2071796/|title=Yippies in Love: Exploring the Vancouver riot - of 40 years ago|website=The Globe and Mail|access-date=22 June 2011}}[http://www.theatreintheraw.ca/images/yippies-a-love-story/yippies-in-love-poster.jpg POSTER : YIPPIES IN LOVE] Theatre in the Raw, Vancouver East Cultural Centre, 2011 == 2000s == In 2000, a [[Hollywood]] film based on the life of Yippie co-founder [[Abbie Hoffman]], titled ''[[Steal This Movie]]'' (spoofing the title of his book, ''[[Steal This Book]]''), was released to mixed reviews, with [[Vincent D'Onofrio]] in the title role.{{imdb title|id=0161216|title=Steal This Movie}} Noted film critic [[Roger Ebert]] gave the movie a positive review,{{cite web|url=https://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/steal-this-movie-2000|author=Ebert, Roger|title=Steal This Movie|website=RogerEbert.com|publisher=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=August 25, 2000}} remarking that although it is often difficult to credibly bring historic events to life, he believed the movie succeeded: {{Quote|text=Abbie Hoffman is seen wearing an American flag shirt and getting in trouble for desecrating it; the movie cuts to footage of [[Roy Rogers]] and [[Dale Evans]] yodeling while wearing their flag shirts. Hoffman insisted that the flag represented all Americans, including those opposed to the war; he resisted efforts of the Right to annex it as their exclusive ideological banner. Vincent D'Onofrio has an interesting task, playing the role, since Hoffman seems on autopilot much of the time. He is charismatic and has an instinctive grasp of the dramatic gesture, but can be infuriating on a one-to-one level ...}} The Yippies continued as a small movement into the early 2000s.{{cite web|url=http://cannabisnews.com/news/9/thread9552.shtml|title=Yippie Central|publisher=New York Today|author=Moynihan, Colin|date=30 April 2001}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/04/15/nyregion/still-agitating-forget-arthritis-old-yippies-want-steal-convention-but-city.html|title=Still Agitating (Forget the Arthritis); Old Yippies Want to Steal Convention, but City Balks|author=Archibold, Randal C.|website=New York Times|access-date=2004-04-15}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/08/23/nyregion/yippies-protest-near-bloomberg-s-town-house.html|title=Yippies Protest Near Bloomberg's Town House|author=Moynihan, Colin; Healy, Patrick|website=New York Times|access-date=2004-08-23}} The New York chapter was known for their annual marches for decades in New York City to legalize [[cannabis (drug)|marijuana]];{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/03/nyregion/pot-smokers-march-is-out-of-the-park.html|title=Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park|publisher=New York Times|author=Allen, Mike|date=3 May 1998}}Marcelle Clements, ''The Dog Is Us, and other observations'', p.46-47, Penguin Books, 1987, {{ISBN|978-0140084450}} NYC Yippie [[Dana Beal]] started the [[Global Marijuana March]] in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://gvshp.org/blog/2016/04/20/from-sip-ins-to-smoke-ins-marijuana-and-the-village/|title=From Sip-Ins to Smoke-ins…Marijuana and the Village|website=OffTheGrid : Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation|author=Morowitz, Matthew|access-date=2016-04-20}} Beal also continued to crusade for the use of [[Ibogaine]]{{cite journal |author1=K.R. Alper |author2=H.S. Lotsof |author3=C.D. Kaplan | year = 2008 | title = The Ibogaine Medical Subculture | journal = J. Ethnopharmacol. | volume = 115 | pages = 9–24 | pmid=18029124 | doi = 10.1016/j.jep.2007.08.034 | issue = 1}}{{cite web|url=https://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle/2009/mar/13/feature_boston_ibogaine_forum_sh|title=Feature: The Boston Ibogaine Forum -- from Shamanism to Cutting Edge Science|author=Smith, P.|website=StopTheDrugWar.org|publisher=Drug War Chronicle|access-date=13 March 2009}} Beal was a forum participant. to treat heroin addicts.{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/orange-beef-press/dana-beal-wants-to-cure-heroin-addiction-with-ibogaine-400b2535c39|publisher=Orange Beef Press|website=[[Medium (website)|Medium]]|author=Arnett, Andrew|title=Dana Beal Wants To Cure Heroin Addiction With Ibogaine|access-date=6 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://chrisfowlie.com/2009/09/dana-beal-yippie-for-drug-treatment/|title=Dana Beal: Yippie for drug treatment!|author=Fowlie, Chris|website=ChrisFowlie.com|access-date=21 September 2009}} Another Yippie, [[A.J. Weberman]], continued the deconstruction of the poetry of [[Bob Dylan]] and speculation about tramps on the Grassy Knoll through various websites. Weberman has for a long time been active in the [[Jewish Defense Organization]]. Throughout this decade, NYC Yippies frequently joined in local anti-[[gentrification]] protests over the continuing transformation of New York's [[Lower East Side]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/15/nyregion/15protest.html|title=East Village Protesters Denounce All Things Gentrified. It's a Tradition.|author=Moynihan, Colin|website=New York Times|access-date=2008-06-15}} In 2008, there was a very public feud between [[A.J. Weberman]] and fellow founding-Yippie, popular New York radio host [[Bob Fass]] of [[WBAI]]. The incidents around this feud briefly brought increased local attention to Yippies,{{cite web|url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2008/04/01/yippie-apocalypse-in-the-east-village/|title=Yippie Apocalypse in the East Village|website=The Village Voice|author=Rayman, Graham|access-date=2008-04-01}} particularly since this occurred around the same time a new PBS movie about the Chicago riots was getting widespread national attention.{{Cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/independentlens/chicago10/yippies.html|title=CHICAGO 10 : The Film|publisher=PBS|date=22 October 2008}} The film featured [[Hank Azaria]] as Abbie Hoffman and [[Mark Ruffalo]] as Jerry Rubin,{{imdb title|id=1309975|title=Chicago 10}} touching off a new generation's interest, since both are now deceased and have passed into legend. In 1989, [[Abbie Hoffman#Death|Abbie Hoffman]], who had been suffering intermittent bouts of depression, committed suicide with alcohol and about 150 [[phenobarbital]] pills.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/19/us/abbie-hoffman-committed-suicide-using-barbiturates-autopsy-shows.html|title=Abbie Hoffman Committed Suicide Using Barbiturates, Autopsy Shows|publisher=New York Times|author=King, Wayne|date=9 April 1989}} By contrast, Jerry Rubin became a fast-talking (and by all accounts, fairly successful) [[Stock market|stockbroker]] and showed no regrets.{{cite web|url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2017/09/19/jerry-rubins-weird-road-from-yippie-to-yuppie/|website=The Village Voice|title=Jerry Rubin's Weird Road From Yippie to Yuppie|author=R.C. Baker|access-date=19 September 2017}} In 1994 he was fatally injured by a car while [[jaywalking]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/11/30/obituaries/jerry-rubin-56-flashy-60-s-radical-dies-yippies-founder-and-chicago-7-defendant.html|title=Jerry Rubin, 56, Flashy 60's Radical, Dies; 'Yippies' Founder and Chicago 7 Defendant|publisher=New York Times|author=Pace, Eric|date=30 November 1994}} By the age of 50, Rubin had broken with many of his previous countercultural views; he was interviewed by ''[[The New York Times]]'', which described him as a "yippie-turned-conspicuous-yuppie." In the interview, he stated that "Until me, nobody had really taken off their clothes and screamed out loud, 'It's O.K. to make money!'"{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940DE5DF1238F935A25754C0A96E948260|title=Jerry Rubin Is 50 (Yes, 50) Years Old|publisher=New York Times|date=16 July 1988}} ==Yippie museum and cafe== In 2004, the Yippies, along with the National AIDS Brigade, purchased the long-time Yippie "headquarters" (which had initially been acquired by [[squatting]]) at 9 [[Bleecker Street]] in New York City {{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/01/garden/yippies-answer-to-smoke-filled-rooms.html|title=Yippies' Answer to Smoke-Filled Rooms|website=New York Times|author=Leland, John|access-date=2003-05-01}} for $1.2 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.nysun.com/article/29241|title=Yippies Apply for a Piece of Establishment|author=Kolben, Deborah|website=New York Sun|access-date=2006-03-16}} After official purchase, it was converted into the "Yippie Museum/Café and Gift Shop",{{cite web|url=http://www.thevillager.com/villager_144/museumwillhave.html|title=Museum will have Abbie's trash, Rubin's road kill|author=Anderson, Lincoln|website=The Villager|access-date=2006-02-01}}{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorkartworld.com/things/things-yippie.html|title=The Yippie Museum|website=New York Art World|date=2007}} housing a multitude of counter-cultural and leftist memorabilia from all over the world, as well as providing an independently operated café that featured live music on scheduled nights.{{cite web|url=http://thevillager.com/villager_185/stealthiscoffeehouse.html|title=Steal This Coffeehouse : Yippies Revive the 60s Vibe|website=The Villager|author=Haught, Lori|access-date=2006-11-15}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/20/nyregion/thecity/20yipp.html|title=At the Yippie Museum, It's Parrots and Flannel|author=Bleyer, Jennifer|website=New York Times|access-date=2008-01-20}} Performers at the café included both nationally known figures and local bands,{{cite web|url=http://localeastvillage.com/2011/12/09/yippee-the-yippie-museum-cafe-gets-back-its-groove/|website=Local East Village|title=Yippee! The Yippie Museum Cafe Gets Back Its Groove|author=Sjolin, Sara|access-date=2011-12-09}} including [[Roseanne Barr]], [[Ed Rosenthal]], [[The Fiction Circus]], and [[Joel Landy]]. The museum was chartered by the [[Board of Regents]] of the [[University of the State of New York]].{{cite web|url=http://www.regents.nysed.gov/2006Meetings/March2006/0306bra1.htm|title=NY Board of Regents – Charter Applications for March 2006|publisher=State of New York|date=September 29, 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060929113834/http://www.regents.nysed.gov/2006Meetings/March2006/0306bra1.htm|archivedate=September 29, 2006|df=mdy-all}} According to the original curator's message, the museum was founded "to preserve the history of the Youth International Party and all of its offshoots." The Board of Directors: [[Dana Beal]],{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/11/nyregion/11yippie.html|title=A Yippie Veteran Is in Jail Far From the East Village|website=New York Times|author=Moynihan, Colin |access-date=2008-06-11}} Aron Kay, [[David Peel (musician)|David Peel]], William Propp, Paul DeRienzo, and [[A. J. Weberman]].[http://yippiecafe.blogspot.com YippieCafe.com]. [[George Martinez (activist)|George Martinez]] was a semi-frequent speaker at the Yippies' Open-Mic, known as "Occupational Hazards/The People's Soapbox," as was [[Andy Stepanian]]{{cite web|url=http://timknoxshoots.wordpress.com/2013/06/13/at-the-yippie-cafe/|title=At the Yippie Cafe|website=timknoxshoots|access-date=2013-06-13}} and [[Captain Ray Lewis]].{{cite av media|url=https://vimeo.com/35688245|title=Philadelphia's Capt. Ray Lewis at The Yippie Cafe 1/25/12 Phone Video Part 1|work=Vimeo|accessdate=May 2, 2016}} In Summer 2013, The Yippie Cafe officially closed.{{cite web|url=http://www.nypress.com/remembering-the-yippies/|title=Remembering the Yippies : Counter-cultural haven on Bleecker Street still alive despite legal struggle|website=NY PRESS|author=Fitzsimmons, Daniel|access-date=4 December 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/06/09/loan-dispute-threatens-a-countercultural-soapbox/?_r=0|title=Loan Dispute Threatens a Countercultural Soapbox|website=New York Times|author=Moynihan, Colin|access-date=2013-06-09}} At the beginning of 2014, the Yippie building (Museum) at #9 Bleecker was sold, closed and permanently cleaned out;{{cite web|url=https://www.celebstoner.com/blogs/preston-peet/2014/01/17/requiem-for-yippie-stronghold,-9-bleecker/|title=Requiem for Yippie Stronghold, 9 Bleecker|website=CelebStoner|author=Peet, Preston|access-date=2014-01-17}} most of the memorabilia and historic materials dispersed among the remaining New York Yippies. As of 2017, the old Yippie building at #9 Bleecker had been totally transformed into a successful [[Bowery]]-area [[Boxing]] club called "Overthrow", deliberately and artfully retaining much of its original Yippie/60s-revolutionary decor. Tourists still drop by to see it.{{cite web|url=http://patterson.no-art.info/activities/2016-10-10_overthrow-fanzine.pdf|title=OVERTHROW FANZINE|author=Patterson, Clayton|publisher=Overthrow Boxing Club|access-date=10 October 2016}} ==See also== * [[1968 Democratic National Convention protest activity]] * [[1971 May Day protests]] * [[Cannabis political parties of the United States]] * [[Freak scene]] * [[Gastown riots]] * [[Human Be-In]] * [[List of anti-war organizations]] * [[List of peace activists]] * ''[[Medium Cool]]'' -
